Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 04:22AM barbe1958 wrote: I had a double mast and am quite happy with it (as far as you can be happy with it, as you mentioned!). I, too, asked for clean and neat. Make sure your doc REALLY understands you do NOT want future recon or they will leave dog-ears which are pouches of fat and skin under your arms that are used for reconstruction later. A lot of the women on this board are disappointed when they wake up! (You can always get an incision revision later if you don't like the look of the scar. I got one on my cancer side due to excess skin left.) The recovery IS easy compared to say, my hysterectomy! There are no bones, organs or muscles involved, so you are dealing with skin issues only. It does tend to get itchy 10 days out or so. Don't take pain meds if you don't need them as they'll only constipate you and keep you lethargic after the anaesthetic. Listen to the 'rules' for afterwards and follow them. Don't try to be a hero, you have the right to recover at your speed. (Some people may jump in and say they had pain, but if it's their first surgery, or they had recon, they may have nothing to compare surgery pain to. As I don't know your situation, please don't be surprised if you find it painful! I wonder if I should have mentioned my experience, but I do want you to know it is easier than reconstruction, that's for sure!) God bless and God speed!

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2013 09:04AM barbe1958 wrote: Hmm, sorry I was right on my last post and it was the size of the tumour your surgeon wanted to talk to you about! But, as you said, the survival rate of 80% (without treatment) is what you had figured WITH treatment!! So you're already AHEAD of the game (and stats are only for the average women)!! You see?? You don't have your treatment plan in place yet which is why you're still hanging in limbo. Once you know what else you are going to do to the breast cancer (if anything) then you will feel so much better!! Do you see how you are kind of still in the waiting game? The fear of mets will lessen with time, but you do need to stay vigilant of your body. You know your body best. Right now your body is taking care of itself by dumping excess weight. Lucky you! The stress of the situation and the surgery all add to the "not hungry" feeling. This too, will pass. Stage 1, 2 AND 3 are all considered Early Stage Breast Cancer. So it doesn't matter what stage you are assigned, the disease is still breast cancer and you will be treated. Normally the higher the stage the more treatment you got, but oncs are beginning to figure out that this "blanket treatment" doesn't work for all, and now all stages are being treated on an individual basis. Being on these boards for 5 years, I've seen more stage one ladies (WAY less treatment!) progress to pass on than stage 4!! Go figure!!! Now treatment is considered on YOUR tumour and it's features. It's a much better position to be in than even five short years ago.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2013 09:51AM barbe1958 wrote: I would gently hold a warm, damp cloth to the gauze that is sticking. As for crying, remember what I said about when it's all over? As women we are strong during the crisis but allow ourselves to "breakdown" when it's all over. That's what you're doing now, you're allowing your body to release the stress you've been holding in. Thank goodness!!!! As for the sentinel node, the latest technology is to only take one. The surgeon would go back in if you need more. This lessens your chance of developing lymphadema, so it's a good thing!!! My surgeon took a couple that were mashed together just to be safe. As well, did your surgeon say she just took one? You may see more than one on the pathology report. As for the fear of the future, you will learn to get nervous only when you get a weird symptom in your body. The "rule" is to wait it out two weeks and if the symptom - say back pain - continues, then you see your doctor. You'll get used to it, sweetie. You're doing great!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 05:13AM barbe1958 wrote: SophiaMarie, you must have seen the "Run For a Cure" charities in your area. There is NO cure for breast cancer. There is only treatment. That doesn't mean you necessarily die of it. Think of all the people with diabetes, asthma, COPD, heart disease. They all have terminal illnesses that they may or may not die from. There would be millions of people living in fear every day. The world would be paralysed and there would be no one out and about to get "hit by a bus"!!!! I know that's a bit dramatic, but I hope you get my point. Life itself is a crap-shoot!!!! EVERYONE has cancer cells floating around in them and it just takes the perfect (or imperfect!) conditions to "turn them on". Your body has done it, once, so far. It does NOT mean it will do it again! Now that you ARE a cancer patient you will be watched like a hawk and be at the front of the line for any tests and scans. You are actually "lucky"!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2013 07:33AM barbe1958 wrote: I was wondering if you were serious about meeting with the Pathologist. How did you pull that off, and why??? The Onc goes over your pathology with you. The Pathologist isn't paid to meet with patients. As for chemo only adding 3%, that is pretty low. Shows what a good position you are in!! The Oncotype test is perfect for you as it will let you know whether to bother with chemo or not. BUT it is based on you taking Tamoxifen for the next 5 years. No point in skipping chemo AND Tamoxifen. Exercise and eating well just keeps your body chemistry flowing correctly. If you are all "inline" inside, there is less chance of that perfect storm to set off with a cancer growth. Also, being healthy will keep your immune system strong, but please understand that there are women who are tri-athletes on here, and vegans and all sorts of healthy women who got breast cancer too!!! So, there is NO magic bullet to guarantee anything in life. But you already know that. Glad you like your Onc. Let us know what your oncotype score is.

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 08:33AM barbe1958 wrote: Overthe1stbighurtle, the injections in your breast were to follow the lymph system to your armpit. The node that picked up the dye first would be your Sentinel Node. They check that node as well as any other that picked up the dye to see if there is cancer in them. Think of the nodes as the drains of your breast. Any cancer that tries to get out of your breast via the lymph system will have to travel through the nodes first. So, by picking out any that turned blue with the dye, they will see if there are cancer cells in the nodes. Years and years ago they would just take out ALL the nodes with horrendous results for the poor women!! This is MUCH saner and safer for you.  The dye drains through your lymph system and not your ducts so there was no reason for your nipple to be sore. How is it now? I researched everything they were going to do to me so I wasn't scared. Until 3 weeks before I had my dye injected in four places, they used to do it directly INTO THE NIPPLE!!!! Can you imagine the pain?????? Thank God they don't do THAT anymore, eh????
Posts.Title: I'm terrified of the recovery room! SophiaMarie barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2013 05:16AM barbe1958 wrote: Sofiamaria, you have valid fears and the fact that you can voice them shows you are aware and on track for what is to come. That is a GOOD thing as you will be able to make decisions as they come up. As for the dye, I had it and it does NOT sting!!! The needles that put it in are very, very thin and perhaps that's the sting he was referring to. It's like having anything injected, you don't really feel where it goes. That's used to help them find the sentinel node; the first node that picks up the dye going into your armpit area should be checked to see if it contains cancer cells. You have at least 21+ nodes in your armpit, they only need the first one and may take another couple for good luck. Some places check the nodes while you're still under and more may have to be taken. You might want to ask that. It's not common anymore to strip rows of nodes out as that could give you future lymph drainage issues. So, hopefully they will only take out the ones with cancer in them. That means they did their job and stopped the cancer from moving further into your system. That's a good thing! Your surgeon probably won't have any answers for you when you wake up except that it "went as expected". It's up to pathology to figure it all out and that takes days. The lump taken out might be big, but the cancer inside might be tiny. The surgeon won't know if the nodes taken out were cancerous or not. Just because they take up the dye doesn't mean they are cancerous. The surgeon wants to take a bigger lump than the cancer is expected to be because you want "clean margins". That means that there are no stray cancer cells at the edges of your lump which could mean there are even more stray cells wandering around. You need to have a certain "clean" area around the cancer to show the surgeon got it all. This won't be known until pathology tells the surgeon they either found something or didn't. So you see, the surgeon won't be able to scare you any more than you already are. Fear at this time is a good motivator to get things done. It's when your body shuts down and you can't function that you have to worry. At that point, a good long chat with your cancer team to let them know you are frozen in fear will allow them to help you. There are meds to help you get back on track. It can be paralyzing to hear you have cancer. We know. You will learn the difference between fear and vigilence; a way to keep on top of your own health. Learn your body. If anything bugs you for more than two weeks, see your PCP. A lot of us have ruined good years in worry and fear and gained nothing for it. But don't be naive either. You got cancer once, that doesn't give you a "get out of jail" card for life. Your body now knows how to create it. Remember: You don't have to be brave, you just have to show up! Good luck, sweetie, the way you are articulating now shows you have "it" all together. Make sure you cry though - in the shower or car - it has to come out at some point, so be ready.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 01:51PM barbe1958 wrote: A couple of things. Why do people thing the SECOND opinion is the right one??? What if you get the wrong advice from the second guy?? It's one thing to switch docs because you want a more compasionate one....but waiting to see a second doc does eat up time. As far as time goes, you can take up to 3 months, 90 days from surgery to still be effective, so don't panic. There's one thing to be your own advocate, but you have to trust that others are doing their job. You might get labeled negatively if you are constantly checking that people are doing their job. It could be adding to your stress load where you don't need that. UNLESS, you have taken on this journey AS your job. That is different. Most of us were working while going through this a we had work to distract us. Maybe you're using the monitoring of your tests as your "work". Know what I mean? Otherwise, hand it off. Oncotype testing will take as long as it needs and phone calls won't speed it up. You've already learned that different offices give different result times and are confusing yourself. WE all know that waiting is hell. THEY don't understand it. You will see this time and time again. Get used to it. Limbo is a horrid place to be. Take up knitting!! Seriously, you need something that you have to concentrate on (not like TV!) to keep your mind busy. As for the guy with the brain tumour. My DH has THREE (all benign). The day will be boring for you and his wife. Are you SURE she wants you there? It may be a private time for him and his wife. Just be sure. Again, you have enough to worry about yourself. As you point out, dealing with him is bringing up your issues. You have to learn when to pull back and take care of yourself. If you can't be 100% support for the wife, then you could be a load on her to keep YOU calm!! I'm being nice about this. Seriously. I'm worried about YOU. Not the guy with the brain tumour or the MO's office that's nice or even the Oncotype office. Just take a deep breath and decide what is truly important this second for YOU. I may be as simple as a cup of tea.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 07:42AM barbe1958 wrote: You're probably not going to like the answers you get so I'll start you off. ER+/PR+ and HER2- recurrence rates increase after 5 years, not within the first 5. Nothing that happens in 3 months can't wait until 6 months. If you have a pain or symptom that continues for more than 2 weeks, then you make an appointment. Finding mets now or later does not increase or decrease your mortality. It would only treat the symptoms sooner, that's all. Don't borrow trouble...you can't live month to month worrying about a recurrence or cancer will win over your life. We have very similar time frames and I have just learned to "move on". God I hate that term! But, I don't ever forget that I have/had cancer, I just don't worry the same way I used to. We are ALL just one diagnosis away from Stage IV. It doesn't matter what stage you are now. That was just for your treatment plan. Best of luck and gentle hugs....

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2010 01:46PM barbe1958 wrote: You're not getting reconstruction which will help your pain level tremendously. Also, no node removal. The breast tissue they take has no bones, organs or muscles in it so there is very little to "feel" afterwards. The most annoying is the drain(s), but very doable. You won't need to sleep in a recliner as you aren't getting a recon. Get in and out of bed using your ab muscles not your arms. The hardest thing will be to wash your own hair. Get a friend to do it over the kitchen sink or your hairdresser. Driving can be tricky as you don't realize how many chest muscles you use to turn and check your lanes. Bending down can put a lot of pressure on your chest too. So as Lisa says, bring things to counter level, both up and down. I used a zip up hoodie and carried the drains in the pockets. I left the hospital without a pain med and I have Fibromyalgia and was terrified of being in too much pain. No problem. The second annoying time is when the nerves start to regenerate and they ting and zing and ITCH!!! Are you going to wear a prothesis? If you just get one breast off, you'll still have to wear a bra... Good luck!

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2013 06:51AM barbe1958 wrote: Champy, it is very common for people in specialized medical fields to experience the fear of what they work with every day. A change of work, like you said, might be best for you!! Breast cancer cells double every 180 days. That's 6 months. So if you haven't had any significant growth then you KNOW and so do the docs, that it isn't breast cancer. I hope that alone can give you some peace of mind! That's why they have that horrid "watch-and-wait" time period before they do another test. Hormones affect cysts in your breasts and the timeline of your period does as well. They have to know your cycle to do the tests at the right time, so keep a schedule to help them. All in all, it looks like you're in good hands with your breast surgeon and may you two have a very benign relationship for another 7 years!! I wish you only the best, sweetie, enjoy your new babe.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2016 06:22AM barbe1958 wrote: I had a lumpectomy with dirty margins. It was my fourth biopsy. I had told the surgeon if it came back cancer I wanted to have a double mast. I got it 6 days later! I've never looked back, and I've stayed flat. I have no "shame" about walking around flat, in fact, I look slimmer though I weigh a lot! My breasts used to enter the room before me, even after a reduction. I'm so glad to have the weight off my neck and back. I don't wear a bra or prothesis or have recon. I do make sure that whatever I wear against my skin is sooooft. In fact, sometimes I feel very, very sexy/naughty by having a bare chest under my clothes. My grandkids are growing up with me like that so it's normal to them. My first grandson, at about 2 1/2, while on my lap sat up and reached back and sort of felt my chest then turned back and cuddled up. My daughter said I can hold my grands closer to my heart this way. Another grandson on my lap poked my belly and asked if I had a baby in there. I told him that was a very good question (for a 4-year old), but sadly no, NaNa didn't have a baby in there. I've done the Survivor Lap at the Relay for Life 4 times and wear my snug t-shirt with pride. I like to walk past all those ladies dancing around in pink frilly bras over their t-shirts and watch the "penny drop" when they realize what breast cancer really is. Everyone once in a while I will dream about my breasts and how sexy they were. I asked my surgeon where those wonderful nerves that used to be attached to my nipples went. He told me to have fun looking for them.... The only time I cried was when I had to climb onto the operating table. The staff were surprised....like, duh! I had to get an excision revision a couple of months later for excess skin and was telling the surgical team how well I was doing. I had just said "breasts aren't very important after all" when another doctor entered the room and said "breasts are VERY important"! They slapped the gas over my face before I could start laughing. I'm sure he got shit from the team for such a stupid remark. LOL

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 09:33PM barbe1958 wrote: Frankie, I know you and you know me. I think the fact that you are even posting the question is to get a little nudge from the community. I know you are strong enough to make this decision yourself but respect the need for input from your peers. I think a 3-day program would actually give you LESS stress than going back full-time so that's a no-brainer. I know you will have to learn new things anyway, so the new position is just the same as going what to what you used to know. The pay being the same for less time worked is easy to swallow. It's the fear of getting sicker that scares you. That scares everyone at every stage. Even people without cancer worry sometimes. You are not marrying this job, you are only performing it. Even actors have "seconds, or stand-ins" in case they are ill. It is a fact of life. You would be part of a team again and that team would have to pull your weight if needed. If the contract is only for one year that is not a long committment. If anything came up, you focus on the new health issue as aggressively as you did the last one, then back to work, if and when you want. This is about YOU, not about fulfilling a contract. Nothing is guaranteed in life. Now if this is just you nervous about having an interview.....get over it! You've had brain cancer - you can do anything!!!!! Just do it!

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 07:24AM barbe1958 wrote: Please, please, please, keep in mind that an Oncotype test result is BASED ON THE ASSUMPTION THAT YOU ARE GOING TO GO ON TAMOXIFEN!!! There is no point wasting your insurance dollars if you have no intention of taking Tamoxifen. And yes! Even Stage 0 can get to mets. Last year on this board we lost a wonderfully talented artist from South Africa who started out with DCIS. I needed to get back to work as fast as I could as I am the sole bread winner in my house. I had a double mast without reconstruction and took off between Christmas and New Years in 2008/09. There is much less residual or ongoing pain without reconstruction. I do not know what PMPS is, but as for RSD I can't find anything on staging, that is new to me. I have Fibromyalgia and that was my fear - ongoing pain. Some women who have reconstructed with FM have had to get their implants out due to constant pain. I made sure I stayed on top of my pain but left the hospital without even Tylenol 3's. A mast doesn't touch bones, organs or muscles so there is very little pain. When you start putting in TE's and bringing tissue from other areas of your body you will be in more pain. I now have Costochondritis which is a result of the surgery, but at least I'm alive.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2013 05:22PM barbe1958 wrote: pomcpom, cancer doubles every 180 days. That's every 6 months! So something tiny becomes 2, then 4, then 8, then 16, then 32, then 64...etc. You can see how something WOULD show up in 6 months! That's why it's a normal "wait and see" period of time. Other things can grow too, like cysts, but to be sure, "the best lump is the one in a jar!" Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2011 09:45AM barbe1958 wrote: My kids are a lot older than yours but when I got the cancer word, I prayed I'd see them get married. They did! Then I prayed I'd get to see grandchildren. And I have...3 of them!! It seems like I keep making milestones and getting to that and then worrying that if I don't have another goal then I'll just give up and not have 'anything to live for.' I know that sounds kind of dramatic, but hey, that's the way we think. I was so worried about recurrence in the beginning that I actually came to terms with it. I will recur. I just don't know when. I have accepted it, I will be prepared, it will not send me into a tailspin. I am ready. BUT, I don't live like I'm dying, I live like I'm still living. Prepare for the worst - but expect the best. You are not alone in your thinking, trust me! Besides the pharmaceutical assistance I get for stress, I've just started seeing a counsellor. I told her the first time I met her that my next medical crisis had better be terminal because I have no fight left in me! Now when I remember saying that, it gives me goosebumps....how sad is that statement!!
Posts.Title: How Do I Deal.. Pure jennyboog

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 09:14AM barbe1958 wrote: Remember, you also threw everything at your cancer!! You did all you could..and while pregnant too! Some women might not have had the guts to do what you did. Give yourself credit for that one, too. There ARE drugs being invented. Can you imagine how the HER2+ women felt when Herceptin came out?? But how hopeless they must have felt before it.... I know what you mean about being sad for them, not you. I even taped one of those Hallmark books for both of my married kids before they were even pregnant! I didn't know if they would ever hear 'NaNa's' voice otherwise. We can eat our guts out thinking of things like that..... I hate that I have physical restrictions as well as cancer behind me, as I don't want my grands to remember NaNa as being 'ill'. I want them to remember the kooky lady who lets them do things their mothers don't! You also have to deal with post-tramautic-stress-disorder. I explained to another 'survivor' as I waited for my bone scan today. "You were sent to the front line of the war you didn't ask to be in", I saw her husband watching me and nodding, "bullets were fired at you! They were so close to you that you heard them pass, maybe they even nicked you. But you didn't die! You are okay! It's hard to wrap your head around how close you were to your own death, no one wants to see that." We have the technology to help these kinds of feelings and you have the right to feel safe. Please ask for help. You did when you posted this thread, but we can't hold your hand as you go through this...just virtually. Hugs!

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 07:13AM barbe1958 wrote: Elizabeth and other Stage IV's. I pray to God I haven't been one of those Pollyannahs... I, too, hate when I hear "oooo, we have to get a cure now!" or "stay positive, stay strong" blah, blah, blah.What good would that do someone already a stage IV? I have had over a dozen family members die of cancer and have watched this disease go through pretty much every body part a human has. I never pretend to know how you feel. I hope you have never thought I was so presumptive! We all need our time to crash and burn every once in a while. This is a good, safe place to vent and rage. I tend to form my responses based on the post. Do you want a spritual response? I will respond as such. Do you just need a hug? I've got one for you. I don't respond, though I do read, a lot of threads that I just keep my mouth shut on. I respect the issues that are being faced by the poster and unless I have a connection, I will not add my own feelings. I responded to this one as Elizabeth and I go back quite a number of months and I'm waiting for her to come back to Canada. How do I find these threads? Some of my best "friends" on this site are Stage IV and I always check the "Active Topics" to see what's happening. I have cried for a number of sisters since I've been on here and have watched others pass in silence, knowing my words would mean nothing. But, I do have an interesting observation to make, one that I have felt since my diagnosis, and strangely before. Recently I was with about 9 other bc ladies (HATE the word survivor, and bootface, by the way) and I asked, "Do you feel you will die of breast cancer." To the last person, we all said YES. None of us were an advanced stage. Interesting, I am not paranoid. I know I could never mention that on any other post but one like this as newbies would freak out. I do not read these threads to be morbid or to show pity, but to learn. It takes a lot of guts to spread your soul out for everyone to see and I respect that.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 08:04PM barbe1958 wrote: Firstly, breathe. Don't panic. IF it's cancer, it's been there for a while, and a couple of months won't make a difference unless it's popping out of your skin. It's not, is it? My mammo was Oct 1st and my diagnosis was Dec 10th of 2008. I had a doulble mast Dec 16th. There's a lot of time to think carefully now, so take the time to do research. You might make a rash decision if you go forward in panic mode, so slow down. There is no reason to believe that they would "go for mastectomy" anyway. A 3 cm mass might turn out to be a 1 cm tumour surrounded by pissed off cells! They need to see your scans and do their own assessment before they would consider a biopsy. Be glad that you are moving forward to a cancer centre and not being told to wait 3-6 months then go back! Keep posting on this thread so we can follow your news. Don't keep making up new threads or we'll lose you and you'll think no one cares! You'll get the same advice no matter where you post, we have walked this road before you..... Good luck.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 09:40AM barbe1958 wrote: Mom, I can TOTALLY understand your fear of the test not being better worded. I think they have to be cautious when there is not exactly a diagnosis to provide and that could be why they say "suggestive' meaning they didn't actually see a fibroadenoma, but the cells were building up into that pattern. 4 samples is more than enough to test, they may have divided 2 of them to create 6 or they just fell apart. I just had a biopsy with only one sample and I'm sort of deep down questioning it as you are. Mine said 'suboptimal sample' which to me means they didn't have enough to test. But, I'm going with no sign of cancer and running with it. What you saw on the ultrsound screen (if you did) seems very big, but if you consider how fine the needle is that is going into it, you realize how small the tumour really is. So even if they missed it this time, if it was cancer, it is way too small to count. Your body may even take care of it for you. Our immune systems are pretty good for things like that. That's why you'll hear of someone having their cancer disappear. It is SO scary once you start the googling and discussion forums and realize that it is all so very real. There are SO many women with breast cancer, but treatments are getting more accurate as time goes on. You may have another biopsy or two in the future if your breasts seem to be the kind that 'grow things', so you'll get used to the wordage. Next time you may see 'benign fibroadenoma' and know that it is all good. Good luck, sweetie!
Posts.Title: Can someone help me read my path report? Momnjackson dlb823

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 09:57AM barbe1958 wrote: I had a cyst once when I was 21 that was so big it was causing problems in lifting my left arm!!!!! I had that one out!! The bigger the cyst or fibroadenoma, the more odds it's not cancer. The fact that it fluctuates with your period (the hormones!) is another way to tell it's a cyst. But, sometimes large cysts have cancer in the centre. The cyst is the body's way of trying to enclose it. If it really bugs you and insurance will pay, get it out. But you will have a scar and it's under general anaesthetic. The divot caused by the surgery will eventually fill in so you aren't misshapen. If you read the bottom of a lot of the posts, you'll see that most ladies are dealing with tumours of ONE cm or less. That is the size of your baby fingernail.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2016 03:09PM barbe1958 wrote: Here's another option to throw in the mix. I had early stage cancer with no treatment except surgery (double masts as my margins were dirty). Now, as a stage IV with a recurrence of the same cancer, I can do hormonal treatment and rads. I got 7 years out of my masts. If I'd had rads and an AI then, I would be saying, hey, I got 7 years out of my treatment! Even the surgeon the first time said to "save the big guns until next time". I'm glad I did as now my "big guns" are really little guns at this point. I still have the big guns available to me. I have a cancer that is less than 2% of all breast cancers - Papillary. There was so little known about it in 2008 that my surgeon Googled it and there were only 3 posts - all on the same woman. We treated it as IDC and as it was ER+ and slow growing, knew chemo wouldn't work anyway so I didn't even consider it. Now there are all kinds of tests to see if chemo will help someone! Just 7 short years ago it was an automatic chemo/rads combo. Then Tamoxifen for 5, now 10 years. So I would be off Tamoxifen now anyway. Would my cancer have recurred? I dunno. Would the chemo and/or rads done worse damage to my system? Maybe. I'm the one famous around here for saying your odds are either 100% or 0%. I mentioned it back in 2008 and got jumped all over for saying it that way, but it's true! You either recur or you don't. You either make it, or you don't. I know women who started with DCIS who are no longer with us here, and ones that have been stage IV the entire time I've been here! So there's your logic.

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2016 03:34PM barbe1958 wrote: Perry, I can't see the need for urgent care, surely? It's not an emergency and needs to be checked out carefully. You will probably get more mammos and ultrasounds than you want, and then a possible biopsy to see what you're growing. It takes normal breast cancer 180 days to double in size. That's 6 months. If you're growing that fast it's probably a fluid filled cyst. I had 4 biopsy and cyst removals before I was finally diagnosed with breast cancer at 50. My first cyst was removed at 21. I went through 29 years of abnormal mammos and biopsies and cyst removals and more testing....I get what you're saying. If you recently had surgery, you must make sure the area in your breast isn't infected now by bacteria that could be going through your system. So, you do need to get it checked, just not in a panic. Good luck, sweetie. Let us know how it goes.

I had to take 2 1/2 weeks off as one of my drains had to stay in 22 days and I went to work right from the surgeon's office. Now there is quite a tight feeling as if there isn't enough skin to stretch across. I have had cream rubbed into the incision every night since my steri strips came off to try to keep the area supple. I have started to exercise with a large elastic strip to build back muscle, so I guess it's working the area. I don't need further treatment as mastectomy was my best option. I opted for a double so I didn't have to get recon or wear foobies. I am quite happy flat after years of 42Ds and everyone at work thinks I'm so brave... I was off through Christmas and New Year's where I got 3 days stat holiday pay and I had 5 days of sick days for the year, so that all helped. Keep us posted on your surgery dates!

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 11:09PM barbe1958 wrote: I just had a double mx last week at let me give you ladies some peace of mind. I have fibromyalgia which intensifies pain so badly that they usually start giving me pain meds before they even cut me open. I was stunned by how little it hurt! Even my surgeon admitted it is really a deep skin cut. There are no organs, bones or really any nerves involved. I had a reduction years ago that was quite painful as they have to sew the aureola back on! Even my hysterectomy was bad. This is no where near what I expected. Trust me. I wore a soft tank shirt to the hospital with a zip up hoodie with pockets. The pockets are great to put the drains in without having to worry about pins. Pull up pants and slippers I can slip into, not have to use hands to put on. I was worried about sleeping too, as I had both breasts off. I just put an extra pillow under me in bed and propped up one side with a body pillow. I slept like a log, probably because the stress of waiting was over! Leaning back to reach the pillow may require help at first, but getting up is easier if you roll to the side to get off the bed. As no abdominal muscles are involved in the surgery, feel free to flex those abs!  Don't just worry about reaching up. I try not to reach higher than my shoulder and haven't felt the pinch since I learned that. Your sutures will be different and I had a sentinel node biopsy as well. Worry a little bit about bending over searching for something you stored low. You will feel pressure and possibly pain build up in your chest. Keep stuff at counter height and put a TV tray by your bed so you don't have to reach back for your night table. Magazines are easier to concentrate on in the hospital and you may want candy or something to suck to keep your throat moist. Your throat will be tender from the intubation and ice is wonderful to have access to.  I found getting "dressed" everyday has helped me feel not so "sick". That only means putting the same hoodie back on and slipping up my pants, but it does feel better than pj's. Tomorrow I am having my husband wash my hair over the kitchen sink. I haven't had a shower since last Tuesday and even the home nurses say not to put your body through that kind of stress. A warm facecloth can reach anywhere you want! I am worried about the one above who mentioned a tight chest. You will get that feeling, especially when the wound starts to heal. Itchy too! The drains are the biggest hassle though. Be prepared.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 07:27PM - edited Dec 27, 2008 07:28PM by barbe1958 Oh, another thing to bring to the hospital that saved my sanity was really good ear plugs! There is so much noise there and even though I was semi-private, my roommate would talk on the phone or use her TV and that was annoying enough until I found out she snored at night! The ear plugs kept me safe and soundless in my own little world and my IV bag would get changed at night without even waking me up! These are not swimmers ear plugs, they are like dense sponges that you twist up then put in your ears and let them expand into the space of your ear. I let my roommate know I was using them at night and sometimes through the day to nap. That kept her from trying to chat. She was in for a rotator cuff and not very sympathetic to my breast cancer cause!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 01:55PM barbe1958 wrote: Perhaps the stress of treatment and the fear of her disease is adding to the high blood pressure. Have the docs considered that? Perhaps when she's all done treatment and considered free of cancer, she will have a lower reading. This is a scary place to be!! Also, there is a phenomenon called "White Coat Syndrome" where patients react adversely to their blood pressure being taken and it raises the readings. It is a temporary situation and her pressure would return to normal when she's back home. Either way, she's in good hands with her team. They have to treat what is happening to her now.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2010 04:17AM barbe1958 wrote: The "map" may be showing where it is supposed to go normally, but your underarm can't take that load. You have to start by clearing your good side by doing neck, underarm and chest on the good side and the drawing the lymph away across your chest from bad side to good. The hope is to have your good side take the load from your bad side. Then when you have done that, you can draw anything left down to the front quarter of your torso and the same in the back. I think of it as "bra line" if I still wore one.....

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 05:37PM barbe1958 wrote: I used to have very painful breasts as I was growing up. I was a 32D at age 13!! My breasts were tender at most times, not just around my period, which is normal. Have you started your period yet? It is very, very common for your breasts to be tender at your period time. If you haven't started you periods yet, perhaps this is a sign that you are about to! Cysts are also very common and I had 3 removed and/or drained; the first one at 21 years old. Lumps are scary and your mind probably has trouble thinking about anything else. Why don't you get it checked out before school starts back, so you can start with a clear mind? As a Mom, if my daughter had come up to me and said, "Gee, Mom, I seem to have a lump or two in my breasts. I'm too shy to show you (or not), but can we have a doctor look at them?" That wouldn't offend me at all, as I always taught my kids to respect body-privacy areas. My daughter did tell me that she had sore breasts when she was about 14, but I was able to tell her that was normal.  You will feel much better if someone besides yourself takes a look. No one but a professional can assure you of anything though, not even your best friend, but sometimes fear shared is fear divided. Good luck sweetie! Keep us posted here so we know how you're doing. ((((((((((( Hugz )))))))))))

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2014 12:10AM barbe1958 wrote: The bigger one was just like you described it; like a pea under the skin. That one turned out to be an undissolved stitch. I wanted to see it all and it wasn't worth going under for. The surgeon afterwards said he realized he should have done it in an operating room instead of a side room once he realized how large my abdomen lump was.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 01:33PM barbe1958 wrote: I think part of the concern with the docs is that the oxygen hit that the tumour gets during the lumpectomy can cause it to grow quite aggressively. As well, there is the chance of 'seeding' from the biopsy, where stray cancer cells are dragged through healthy breast tissue. Grade 3 is the highest and most aggressive breast cancer can get. If you were Grade 1, perhaps a longer wait won't matter. I agree with those that say to do it and then go on holiday. But that's just my 2 cents...mileage may vary.

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2016 04:35PM barbe1958 wrote: Jen, the MRI is the gold standard, so if anything was in your lungs it will get caught if it's big enough. An x-ray wouldn't catch anything that is still tiny. As for hereditary, less than 12% of breast cancers are due to family history so that's not even in the picture, really. While you were mentioning your Mom and thyroid cancer, I knew there had to be another primary as thyroid cancer can only grow in the thyroid and not spread. Sorry to hear it was her lungs. I'm very surprised that you got the gene results so fast!!!! Microcalcs aren't usually IDC, are you sure they didn't say DCIS? Of course you are nervous and anxious, that's perfectly normal and gives you the momentum to get something done about any diagnosis you get. You are now in "fight" mode and that is good. Keep it up. As for your shortness of breath, it's Spring....do you have any allergies? You are not alone, please repost here when you get news so we are updated. Good luck, sweetie!

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 04:50AM barbe1958 wrote: Well, then, let me tell you. I have had lumpectomies in the past and last year's mammogram in August showed two areas of concern that they then decided would be okay. Then in May of this year I noticed rusty spots in my brassiere. I normally wear a dark bra and this day it was a light one. Checked for scratches but found none, then promptly forgot about it. I had been experiencing weird chest pains on my left side so bad that I had an angiogram in September of 2007. Then 2 week Holter monitors in May of 2008. Nothing showed up, but with my history of high blood pressure (on meds for 15 years) they had to watch it. Finally in June of this year I thought, hey, I wonder if the chest pain could be breast? As I had just turned 50, I was allowed to book my own mammo. I called in early June and was given October 1st as the first appointment. It was done that quickly because I had suspicious results before. (That's quick!) On October 1st, I sat in front of the mirror with the breast specialist and when I took off my bra I looked down and noticed dark blood coming out of my left nipple! Boy what a shock that was. Right in the imaging department! I was understandable upset and the lady tried to reassure me. When I got to the mammo I was worried about the procedure as a number of years ago a mammo had burst one of my cysts and I had to have surgery to clean it up. On this day, the technician was very blase about the whole thing until blood started to run onto the panels of the machine. She was visibly upset and told me to expect a call for an MRI. So I waited. Finally got a call 5 days later to come in for an ULTRASOUND! I tried to tell the girl it was supposed to be an MRI but she insisted it was for US. It was for the 8th of October. I missed even more work as I went to that appointment. During the test the tech mentioned that my mammo was fine and bleeding could be just anyting. Right, I knew from reading that a unilateral bleeding could only be cancer or papiloma. She called in the radiologist who wanted to see if I could express the blood. So far it had only been spontaneous, I couldn't bring it on and wasn't able to that day. She took my breast and made me bleed, looked up at the tech and said, oh,yes, this is definitely an MRI. The tech took me to booking and tried to give me a November date but I asked for earlier. She looked down at the paperwork and gave me a 2 week later appointment. I went to the MRI and they took the requisite pictures, me missing even more of work, as I work an hour away so I can't go to work, come back for my appointment, return to work and the drive home at the end of the day (4 hours of driving in a 8 hour day?) Surprise! I got a call from my doctor's office (who didn't even know I was going through this as I had booked my own mammo), that the hospital wanted me to go in for a mammo and and US. On my RIGHT breast. ?. I told Sharon that I had just had both and then an MRI on top of that and what the hell!? She said she'd call the hospital and get back to me. Next day she did. They wanted to see me on November 3rd. Just over 1 month from the first appointment. Well, the waiting was hell. I went in for the mammo and the tech was very flippant about the bleeding and only took pictures of my right breast. Told me she would take me up to US and that the left breast was fine (remember, this is the one that is bleeding!). Got my husband and up we went to US. She told me they wouldn't be ultrasounding my left breast and left us waiting. About 5 minutes later she came back in and knelt (!) in front of me and took my hands and told me that yes, they would US my left breast. Then she wished me luck and left. WOW. Went in for the US and they skipped pretty fast over the right breast and into the left. I told the tech I wanted her to find a papiloma. Then I saw a very dark gray area and said maybe that was a papiloma. She got pretty quiet and left to take the pictures to the radiologist. Came back and said they wanted to do a core biopsy right now. On my left breast. Thank God! I told her to go tell my husband and to make sure he knew it was the left breast. The doctor came in and took 3 samples. The bruising is amazing and I expect to hear today (one week later) what the result is. Maybe the roller coaster is finally smoothing out. You have to be your own advocate. Good luck to all!

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 08:28AM barbe1958 wrote: I remember the days before my BLM. I would be watching TV, well, at least facing it....thinking, I have cancer. I have CANCER. I HAVE CANCER. It was so surreal! When we tried to make love one last time, my cancer side nipple bled so it kind of freaked us out. I was very strong and didn't break down even when I hugged my DH (dear husband) good-bye before walking into the OR. In Canada, we walk in and get up on the table ourselves! You feel more in control, I guess, but I would have liked a sedative! When they strapped me down I started to panic a bit, thinking "this is it!". I started to cry a little and a nurse said "What's the matter?" She was very sweet and I told her I was scared. She held my hand and the anaesthesiolgist put his hand on my head and held me until I went under. I will NEVER forget that feeling of being protected and that was a year ago! I chose not to do recon because of the lengthy surgery and recovery. I have other health issues and I had to get back to work fast. Also, my breasts were more of a sex turn on for me! My DH loves my whole body, while I thought of my breasts as the biggie. I'd had a reduction years ago to bring me down to a 42D and the new breasts never really felt like mine. I was worried I'd go through all that surgery to feel the same way. I'm 51 though, and I've nursed two babies (now 28 and 26 and both married!) I wear my flat chest with pride, like a shield of honour. I beat breast cancer! I think of the cancer a lot still. My flat chest I see twice a day while getting dressed/undressed or when I notice someone looking at it. It's interesting to see "the penny drop" as they figure out what must have happened. I've even strolled around a pool for a week at a 5-star resort like I had the 2 best ones out there! I do not feel that my missing curves makes me any less of a woman, and have been told in some ways that my confidence has made me sexier. Go figure!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 01:13PM barbe1958 wrote: I hated people saying "everything will be fine." You don't know that!! No one does. Let her talk and rant and rave and cry and talk about the worst right up to planning her funeral. It's all totally normal. Then she'll get to a point of assigning you duties during her funeral and you'll start to have some fun with it (believe it or not). BUT pace yourself with what SHE needs. Let her draw the humour in to keep the dark side away. She needs to talk about dying. No one lets people do that and it is so relieving! Do NOT tell her to be positive. That is demeaning, implying that she wasn't thinking positive before. Give LOTS of hugs and chocolate (or her favourite treat). Be there. Laugh with her. Cry with her. She will let you know when she doesn't want you around...good luck! Let us know how it goes. And just so you know, the waiting is truly the worst. Once it's diagnosed and a plan is in place time really goes fast. Go over tonight with a bunch of silly board games and tell her you guys are staying until she either passes out from exhaustion or sends you home. But of course, only you can know the parameters of your relationship...

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2016 07:44AM barbe1958 wrote: As well, add Magnesium supplements to your daily routine. Seriously. I have just lost my job, got a new one, was told lump benign, then told lumpectomy showed cancer, now stage IV, husband's CT showed a nodule in his lung which needs follow-up and then he lost his job and all that in 2 months! I've been on Wellbutrin and Zoloft for over 25 years due to a chemical imbalance in my brain. I was able to handle a certain amount of stress, but I started Magnesium supplements last October due to stress at work (thus the lost job) and it has TRULY helped me through these past couple of months. People that know me cannot believe what I am going through! I am able to calmly answer the stupid questions that people ask and have cried only in frustration at stupid things and not depression. I read that almost 90% of people have too low Magnesium levels and it's a crisis that isn't being properly recognized. I wonder if there was something in our food that was taken away. Like, you guys know iodine is in salt. I can't have added salt so I have low iodine in my system and I need that, too. SS please post here as you get the news so we can be there for you. You are not alone, sweetie.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 09:20AM barbe1958 wrote: Josie, you are so new to the diagnosis that you shouldn't even feel that you have to validate your feelings. They are YOUR feelings!!! Of course you want to compare your stats with others with the same diagnosis, but that's a slippery slope. Everyone, and I mean everyone, has a 50% chance of recurrence. You either recur, or you don't. It's a simple as that. But be gentle with others with a lesser diagnosis as they haven't been treated as aggressively as you. Also, an awful lot of woman with only Stage 0 have to get mastectomies!!! I see more mastectomies with DCIS than I do with any other kind. I've been on the board over 3 years and have seen a LOT of Stage 1 and 2 gals jump into the Stage 4 venue. It can happen to ANY of us. We are ALL just one test result away from stage 4. You normally never have to worry about what you post in any forum. But, most ladies check the Active Topics list and all sections come up. That is why you'll find other stages responding to your thread. I'll say, I'd rather be Stage 3, grade 1, than Stage 1, grade 3!! It's the grade that shows the aggression of the cancer. The stage is only used for your treatment plan. Can you imagine one of your kids getting diagnosed with cancer and you tell some friends and one of them says "Big deal, my kid has a higher stage than yours!" Just hearing the word 'cancer' in the same sentence as our own names is enough stress for most of us. Stage and grade at that point don't even matter. Cancer makes it a level playing field. Good luck, sweetie!!

I think English is right, there is more lower grades diagnosed so it's obvious that there would be more that move on to stage 4 than just stage 3 moving on. Stats are just that. A guess. Sometimes based on facts, but as meds have changed so much in the past, especially with the addition of Herceptin, stats that we read now adays don't have much that applies to our current situations. It was me that said you have a 50% chance of recurrence (not 100%!!!). You either get a recurrence or you don't. It's really as simple as that!! Please read my posts for what they are. When I state that "on this board" or "on this forum" I am only relaying my over 3 years of observations ON THIS BOARD.  With almost 15,000 posts of interaction with many different ladies in many different stages, I do find it interesting that the stage 3 gals think they are so different from everyone else! Breast cancer is not curable for ANY OF US. Those of you who got aggressive treatment have a better shot at staying cancer free than those of us who ONLY got a double mastectomy. I know everyone thinks that their treatment was harder than everyone elses, but I think the point is that once you hear your name and CANCER used in the same sentence that the fear that grips our hearts and souls is pretty much the same. I don't think "okay, I only have to be 63% worried because I'm not stage 3". Doi.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 04:43PM - edited Jun 27, 2009 04:45PM by barbe1958 I cried in the car when I was alone and listening to sad music. I never got to the sobbing point as I've had 3 other biopsies and lumps removed in the past so I've been expecting the other shoe to drop for a long time. I, too, am incredulous that you can get an immediate diagnosis. The cells have to be stained and everything, don't they? I got my diagnosis in person with my DH beside me, then I drove to work alone and told everyone I met. It helped to say it outloud a lot, kind of gets it out of your system. I stayed calm and so everyone else did too. I didn't even cry going into the OR for my mastectomies when I had to say "good-bye" to my DH. I did cry though, when they strapped me down. Someone held my hand and the anaesthetist kept his hand on my head while I went under. That's the last crying I did. I think as women, we stay strangely calm during crisises and we do need to vent at some point. That's why it's best to let out whatever you need to in a safe environment. Here is safe. You've come to the right place. We are all here for you. Please update us on this thread so we know how you are doing. Hugs

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 07:49AM barbe1958 wrote: Bosch is the KING of dishwashers!!! They make dishwashers for most of the big guys, like Gageneau and Miele!!!! You have to look to see where the venting is for drying on the inside and make sure you do NOT put a plate up against it. That is one of the problems. The vent is where 99% of us would put a large platter or cutting board and it blocks the vent when you push the rack in and your dishes won't dry properly. Also, take your dish in to the store when you pick your model as the racks are very tight!! They CAN do tons of dishes, but your dishes have to fit between the tines. READ THE MANUAL. Bosch is European so they don't necessarily plan things the way we North Americans do. If you can afford it, go for the model with TWO cutlery baskets. Ours only has one (we wanted a black model) and it fills up quick. Our plates are jammed together and it cleans them EVERY time!! The noises you hear with your top load washer is the gears engaging. It is a strong machine (good choice!) so the action sounds loud. Also, on the dishwasher, Bosch is the quietest out there but it is all relevant. They have inuslation on the back which most units don't so they are good for an island. BUT, because they are a strong machine, again, the gears engaging seem loud. I hear my Bosch where I didn't hear my cheap model. But...only when the gears engage. Not too bad. Use Finish and make sure you always have a blue rinse agent in. The machines are MADE to use the rinse agent, so not using it leaves out part of the equation. When I see that my machine is in "dry" mode, I'll open the door about 6" and let it air dry. Finish is THE best out there, expensive but truly the best.
Posts.Title: Washer Questions garnet131 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 08:53AM barbe1958 wrote: Ah shucks! I'm not amazing...just know everything about appliances, that's why I'm considered and "expert", but amazing sounds so much better!! hehehehehehe My buttons are on the front too. I had them integrated before (accessible only when the door is ajar) but find those ones have fewer options as the space is restricted. It's true about the size of the Bosch. On my cheap dishwasher, I could fit 5 coffee cups along the top. This one only holds 4 and a bit. What do I put in the "bit"??? The shallowness allows for some of the technology the machine has. For instance, it has a triple-filtration system. Big deal? YEP!!! It checks the water to see it it's clear enough for a final rinse. So no matter what you set it at, it will over-ride it if the water that is checked shows otherwise.  Kira, the plate tines are close together for a reason. The Bosch CAN clean plates that seem too close. Hard to believe, but I've challenged mine and it came through. Next appliance??

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 09:19AM barbe1958 wrote: Garnet, don't get me wrong. The CAPACITY is HUGE!!! The inside is smaller but SO well laid out that you can jam everything in and it all cleans. Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 11:27AM barbe1958 wrote: Judy, he should be using the term NED, no evidence of disease. That is the official term for a breast cancer patient that is not showing cancer anywhere in their body. Breast cancer can NOT be cured. Doesn't mean you will die of it. It just means that once you have it, it can come back at any time. But I think of it like I'm NED now, so it's "gone". If it comes back, it's like getting it for the first time....again. Read some of the posts from ladies who are angry that they were falsely led to believe they were cured only to have it come back.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 05:28AM barbe1958 wrote: ER+ breast cancers are slower growing so look better at initial diagnosis, but are the ones that tend to recur more often after 5 years. There are other threads on the board with links which others have found showing this. Triple negative cancers are more apt to recur in the first 5 years if they're going to, so getting to that 5 year mark is good for triple negatives and a time to be more vigilant for the er+.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 08:40PM barbe1958 wrote: Faithful, the other thing to add to Sherri, is that a lot of women go by the "2 week rule". If pain persists or increases over a 2 week period enough, then it's time to mention it to your doctor. Remember as well, though, that you are getting older through all this too! We all freak out at every new ache, no matter what stage we are. The stage IV gals freak out just as much as the stage 0 DCIS ones do. One of the toughest things my onc said to me (besides saying that I had "slipped between the cracks" -her words!) was that if I get mets, the speed at which they are diagnosed has no bearing on the treatment or survival rate. She actually said "It doesn't make a difference." Now, I beg to differ on something like brain mets, wouldn't you??? But bone mets you may not know for years and as some oncs say, it's almost better that you don't know until you are symptomatic, which is why a lot of docs don't do screening tests, but only upon symptoms.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 08:04AM barbe1958 wrote: I am on huge amounts of pain meds too and know that when I become nauseated that I have too much in my system. It's true that your body reacts differently when you are really in pain rather than just trying to get high. You have to stay on top of your pain to keep it under control so it's a fine balance. When I start to feel good for a couple days I reduce the break-through pain meds, oxycodone, but then find I work back up to even higher pain levels. It's a very fine line. I take oxymorphone twice a day and use the codone for break-through pain. Most people would be stoned out of their mind on the meds I take, but I only get a gentle "reminder" that I have taken one. It's like a feeling of relief that the med is starting to work. I drive 2 hours a day on my work commute and I guess legally if I got in an accident I could be charged if they tested me, but no one knows how much I'm on except my docs (and now y'all). My next step is methadone and I know I can't drive with that.  As long as you can function normally, you will not get addicted. It's when you lose interest in other things, like your personal grooming for example, that red flags should go up. We have the rights as humans to be pain free and we have the technology.

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 10:15AM barbe1958 wrote: My own experience?? What the hell do you think I've been speaking from...yours??? I don't understand that sentence. I am always respectful of those with a more advanced stage, and surprise!!!....also those with a LESS advanced stage. I am IDC (Papillary Carcincoma really, but so rare we just get treated as IDC) Stage II with micromets to matted nodes. My surgeon had emergency heart surgery and dropped the ball on my file. It was only from reading this forum that I even knew I should be seeing an oncologist!!! Seriously, I thought I was over it all after my double mastectomies. I had NO chemo, NO rads, NO AI's and NO Tamoxifen or other treatment. NO onc. I finally got one 9 months after diagnosis. She even said that I seemd to "fall between the cracks". It was too late at that point for any further treatment. I am at a watch and wait. I've had 2 biospies for enlarged nodes in my neck and am getting surgery on Feb 6th to take out the large tumour that is in there with them. So, have I had is EASY? NO!!!!! I had a double mast and now a couple years of fear. I honor and respect ALL sisters with breast cancer, not just the ones that think they had it the hardest!! More stage 0 ladies get masts than stage 4. Why does no one acknowledge that? Some stage 3 keep their breasts and then are surprised when they get a local recurrence. Why are you surprised? You kept your breast!! So when you do have to get a mastectomy, maybe you won't mind when "some stage 0" pipes in on the surgery thread to HELP you with your mast!! Now my back is up. I'd better stop typing.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 11:49AM barbe1958 wrote: Beesie you said what Elizabeth said in one sentence. There are more early stages diagnosed, so it makes sense that more early stages recur compared to stage 3. I was thrilled to see that point by Elizabeth because it confirms what I have OBSERVED on these boards for the past 3+ years. Also, there hasn't been hundreds of thousands of statistics (real ones!!) to base any firm stats on. Stats are just like betting or spinning a slot machine. They start new with every diagnosis. You admitted you had to "pull your numbers from the air" so that kind of proves my point. Not enough info being considered quickly enough to make stats more definite. With Herceptin in the past 5 years, any stats made before then are outdated already.  I use the 50% only because it makes it all simpler. If we just had a 3% risk (pulling a "number from the air"), why would anyone bother with chemo, rads or AI's that change your life and give you OTHER diseases to deal with?? I wouldn't risk my heart or lung function over a 0-30% risk factor and I'm sure most women wouldn't. Who would be foolish enough to risk a more important organ of their body??

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 05:08AM - edited Mar 15, 2009 05:09AM by barbe1958 You are right, there are no answers until your test. BUT, 80% of lumps are benign. They often have to come out as they can grow large enough to hurt or cause nerve symptoms which may be what you are experiencing. 30 years ago I had a lump that grew so large my surgeon said if it was cancer I would already be dead!! The sugar drop is probably from adrenaline as your mind tries to deal with the panic you are rightly feeling. Don't let anyone deny you your emotions, but do know that, again, 80% of lumps are not cancer. Be reassured that by the very volume of people on this site alone (over 47,000) that there are an awful lot of us walking around with breast cancer that you didn't even know about! We work, we go to school, we shop, we laugh, we pass you in the streets. We are alive! I had to wait 4 months for a "rush" mammogram. If your lump is cancer, it has been in your body as long as 8-10 years already! Don't let the stress of worry kill your joy of today. I know, easier said than done! But once you have the mammo, the waiting for the results is even harder.. Good luck to you. You are in my thoughts.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 03:19PM barbe1958 wrote: I am an appliance expert...seriously. That's what I do for a living! I just purchased the new Maytag TOP loader without the agitator a couple of months ago. It senses the level of garments and adjusts the water accordingly. I have a HORRIBLE back and just can't bend down for both the washer and the dryer! My Maytag has a clear lid if that is any clue as to which one you find. It wasn't cheap, but oh, so worth it!! The sensors are what make it magic. As for front loads. If you do even a load a week you won't get that musty smell if you're on town water. Someone on well water may get it anyway. There is no way for the front loads to drain all the water out (don't know why it's still a problem...HELLO!!!!!) so any sitting water can get 'skunky'. Leave the door open when you think about it as so many have mentioned. The full agitators just ruin garments as they have to yank your clothes up the pole and then down again. Without the agitators, the new top loads are extremely gentle and just as efficient as the front loads. Of course, if you want pedestals you'll have to get front load.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2009 08:20AM barbe1958 wrote: Mantra, you and I have PM'd, but I do want to add to this post. Mastectomy is NOT painful! Shame on the doctor who told the lady above that she'd be out of her mind with pain! There is no bone, muscle or organs involved. The biggest hassle is the drains. I only wanted to deal with them ONCE. The second hassle is the itching as the nerve ends regenerated. Some people stay on heavy pain meds for too long and get very lethargic and depressed (and constipated!). I left the hospital without even Tylenol. Is is SO doable! The anaesthetic is something you have to get over whether you had a lumpectomy or mastectomy. It does take a toll on your body. Now, reconstruction on the other hand, is another issue! I chose not to reconstruct so I could get back to work as quickly as possible. 2 1/2 weeks after surgery, the day my last drain came out I drove my hour to work.  I didn't want to put something ONTO my body that wasn't mine. Kind of a different kind of thinking than those that don't want to remove something that isn't "sick".... I also didn't want to put my body through the tedious reconstruction process. Mantra, the tumour board at RVH will have to approve your double mast anyway. If they do approve it, you know you did the right thing. Did you want to meet up?

Posts.Content: May 17, 2016 06:53PM barbe1958 wrote: Obviously none of us are doctors. My feelings are; DCIS only grows in the ducts of the breast. IDC on the other hand grows within the breast. If the IDC had good margins that's great. As for the DCIS...I'm a bit confused, how could DCIS within a duct have close margins to tissue left behind? Did the duct get severed? Or was the duct that was taken out so close to the margin? Think of slicing moldy cheese. You can get the mold off the surface, but you don't know if spores are left behind. That's kind of the IDC analogy. But now think of a pot of spaghetti. If you take all the spaghetti out (ducts), what's left behind? I hope you don't think I'm taking your question lightly, but the fact that two doctors have said no means a lot. I just finished radiation for stage IV cancer and it's not an easy treatment. I didn't get radiation after my initial double mastectomy but who knows if it would have kept me from progressing. I got 7 years with no treatment except surgery. That's pretty good. If I'd done chemo and rads I would be just as happy getting 7 years. Breast cancer is so unpredictable there is no way of knowing for sure what is right. Go with your gut and take in the information the doctors have given you. Tamoxifen is a VERY powerful drug and is given to women who progress with more serious breast cancer with mets to the lung and brain and effectively stops the growth. So if your wife has any cells left behind, Tamoxifen should kill them off, if she's ER+. Because I didn't have chemo initially, I can take Arimidex (like Tamoxifen but after menopause) without having to go to harder chemos. My oncologists hope to get one to two years out of it before I progress. At that point I'll have to move on to IV chemos. See, even they don't know what will happen! Some people go for second opinions, and third opinions etc, until they get someone to agree with them. Make sure that isn't your intent. Good luck and I hope someone else pops by.....

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 04:46PM barbe1958 wrote: Forgive me for posting on your thread, but your topic caught my eye. I have spinal stenosis that is just crippling and take heavy narcotics every day (morphine) with oxycodone instant release and oxycontin for breakthrough pain. I find that when I am really bad I catch myself holding my breath. So when the others above mention breathing, it is a fact. I don't know if you have kids, but think about labour. If you breathe with your pain and do some visualizations (I think of myself going "over" my pain to push it down) it can help control the panic of "just how friggin' bad is this going to get?" Also, the renewed oxygen to your body helps feed your muscles to support your body as best it can. I find when someone catches me in tears, if I just say I have a "bad back" they can relate. I mean really, there's no blood or guts running off me, but I truly feel like I could pass out from the pain. Then there are the days that I pray I would pass out. I find the use of a cane or walker gives my bones the needed assistance. It's hard to admit you need them, and I'm in sales in front of the public so it can be off-putting, but I can't survive without the extra support. You are in my thoughts, as I know how debilitating pain can be. God bless.
Posts.Title: Dealing with overwhelming pain in public Honeybear Honeybear

Posts.Content: May 18, 2016 01:38PM barbe1958 wrote: Your wording about saying Tamoxifen "stops it" rather than my words of "kills it" is perhaps more accurate. Either way, the breast cancer can't progress. I've seen women here with brain mets and the lesions disappear after being on Tamoxifen, so it's pretty powerful stuff. Your wife's cancer would have to be ER+ for Tamoxifen to be effective and there is a test she can take when she's been on it for a bit that will tell if her body is using the drug properly. She can also stay on it for more than 5 years - in fact, 10 years is more common now. I will be on Arimidex for life, or until it stops working for me. There are side effects, of course, and she may find it hard to handle, but her body will adjust at some point, so you both have to be patient. The loss of hormones to her body is very difficult, it's like menopause...or think 24/7 PMSing!! Keep us posted on anything else you learn.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 01:52PM barbe1958 wrote: I didn't chose to reconstruct. Today is the two year anniversary of my double mast surgery. Not for a second did I regret my decision. I never hesitated or wavered. Did I think about it?? Of course!! I thought about it for hours,just as you are doing. But once my lumpectomy came back with the diagnosis of cancer AND unclean margins I said "Take them both off." I had already warned the surgeon and he already had me booked. He knew I wasn't kidding. I don't have to wear a bra. I still sweat "under my breasts" though. Always thought I did that due to the heat of my 42Ds. My neck is WAY better arthritis-wise (I'd even had a reduction years ago that got me to 42D). My clothes look neater and most people think I lost a lot of weight. No one really notices....honestly! I mean, do you go around staring at women's chests? I certainly didn't before but I do now! ehhehehehehehe  I wear almost all my regular clothes, just had to get rid of stretchy ones with darts that needed cleavage. Seriously, it took a load of concern and worry off my chest (bilat joke here). I had ALWAYS had to take extra pictures. ALWAYS. The tumour was on my chest wall over my heart (6 o'clock on the left breast) so rads weren't an option. If I only had one breast off, I would have had some sort of reconstruction. The problem is that implants get cold and many women feel that. I live in Canada....need I say more! Also, existing health issues just couldn't validate 10-12 hours of micro-surgery. I'll save that for my heart, thanks. So, hope I helped you some! PM me if you need more info.

I didn't get chemo either. Or Tamoxifen. Or Aromasin. Just a double mastectomy. I went for the mastectomies as I've had 3 other biopsies over the years and this was my fourth. I was so done with worrying about my breasts, so with the cancer diagnosis I said just take them off! I know there is a window of time for radiation or chemo to do any good and I think you're pretty well at it. Your tumour was larger than mine. As ER+, our tumours grow slower. We don't have to worry about a recurrance until after the 5 year mark. As my surgeon said (IDIOT!!) "We'll save the big guns until next time"!!! I'm almost 3 years out and doing fine. Let me know what you decide.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 06:49PM barbe1958 wrote: pil, I had the mastectomies so avoided radiation. Clear margins means that the edges of the lumpectomy have no cancer in them. If there was cancer to the edge of the lump they take out, then they worry that there is still more cancer left in you. So, if you got clear margins (you would have had to have yet another lumpectomy) you don't have to worry about it. I had a lumpectomy first, but as my tumour was SO close to my chest wall I didn't have clear margins. That's when I said just take them off! I tried....I have a full mastectomy on my left side, but a modified one on the right. BUT, due to lymphadema, the left divot has filled in. Gee, thanks for small favours! As for the 1 to 2 percent, that is just a number I threw out there. Please confirm with your doctor what odds you increase by. If it's that low, would it really be worth it? I would go with you if I could!!

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 03:03PM barbe1958 wrote: Beesie, I usually agree with all you say, but this time I don't. Someone posting and then being given "cyber hugs" is all very well and good, but I find someone's experience in the same matter very valuable! Let's talk about drains. Someone posts that she thinks hers are draining too much. So we're just supposed to say "oh dear, hope you feel better"?. I don't think so. IMHO, I think when people respond with different experiences it helps the poster figure out if there is something wrong there or not. I have learned so much by cruising all the threads. I learned my lump after surgery was a seroma. I got it drained. I learned I needed a bone scan. I got one. I learned what lymphadema was so when I was sent to a PT appointment I wasn't confused or scared. I learned how to let people around me help me by letting them know what I needed. I learned a lot and still learn every day. There are posts that are very factual. That's nice; a lot of that I've already googled myself. There are posts that are very exacting on what they need "Help! I need advice!" and others that need specifics "Lumpectomy or Mastectomy?". Those kind of posts are asking for experiences and points and feedback. We can all research to our hearts content but then reach a point where we need to hear from someone who has already gone through what we are facing. People aren't giving opinions, just experiences. I think there is a lot of empathy and sympathy on this board. I don't let isolated incidents skew my feelings about what this board is for - support. I'm sure I've pissed off a number of people as I have so many posts (games, games, games!) but I have learned by doing that. The PM option is a wonderful tool as well. The one thing no one wants is pity, which is why people posting on the stage IV boards are sometimes jumped on, and I don't blame the jumpers. Common courtesy isn't so commom. Either is common sense.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 10:47AM barbe1958 wrote: Deb, I in no way meant to disrespect you or others who have reacted calmly. I apologize profusely to those I have offended in any way. My "beef" is with the lecturing of some posters that we are here to support but not comment or give our experiences or advice. That is just so silly! As I said earlier, it is those experiences that make this such a rich board of information. I may have over reacted yesterday as I do get angry when "told"how to feel or react. As others have said after my posts, stage 0-3 really shouldn't make a difference in sharing information. It is the mis-information that hurts some that is dangerous. I give these ladies a lot more credit for doing a bit more research than to think we have to stop all cross-stage posts. For those that don't know, search "papillary carcinoma" on this very website. It is to be treated as IDC. When I was first diagnosed there was no information anyway on my type of cancer. My surgeon showed up in the operating room with pages of what he was able to get of a medical subscription website that he belongs to! No one knew what to do with me. My tumour was on my chest wall right over my heart. Radiation was not an option for both heart and lungs issues. Chemo, not an option as I'm ER+. Herceptin, nope, I'm HER2-. I'm post menopausal as well...sigh. My surgeon said to "save the big guns till next time". That's why I have an issue on staging. I had 2 nodes with microinvasion but no further treatment. Some people do, some don't. Some people throw everything at it, some take risk into consideration, but, the big point is, we are ALL cursed with the same disease. Breast cancer. Some are just further along the road than others. God bless you all, and again I apologize for my childish behaviour.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 04:20PM barbe1958 wrote: I think you did the right thing by not removing any more lymph nodes. You could still get LE but you've taken less risk this way. I think your back and your breast are two different issues and here's why. You've been told you have DCIS. That means the cancer has NOT left the ducts of the breasts (nodes don't count). I have/had micromets in my nodes too and was told they don't count, either. So that is good that your docs have confirmed that. Nodes with cancer at time of diagnosis are used for staging, but are not considered mets. If you found cancer in your nodes later, then you have progression. The fact that you've had 2 bone biopsies come back benign is very good news! Take that and run with it!! They are treating you nice and aggressively, but until confirmation, I'd say you can play in the Stage IIB threads for a while longer yet! Congrats!!

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 11:17AM barbe1958 wrote: Jenn, FM was not officially accepted by the medical industry until 1991. Before then, we were thought to be pretty much crazy. But they discovered an enzyme "P" in our systems that does not shut off pain sensors. If someone normal touches something hot, they say OW and remove their hand. We say OW, OW, OW and have pain for much longer. It is real. Your onc is a specialist in his field and can't be expected to know everything. Even for surgeries, when I mention the FM I am treated much more aggressively for pain. I am given pain meds before they even start as once the pain is over the top you can't get it back down again. It is finally recognized in the past 10 years or so as a serious disorder. As for your feet, not FM related. I used to stand a lot and was so bad once that I said it was like walking on pencils. The foot doctor was stunned to see that all my metacarpal bones had collapsed! I was literally walking on my bones! He couldn't understand how I had kept walking, but once you get used to being in pain you learn to keep going. Get it checked out. I had to get inserts for my shoes!
