Sunnyone - please, please please do me a favour. Don't use the word "cured" when talking about breast cancer. There is NO cure for breast cancer, only the hope of becoming NED (no evidence of disease) for as long as you can. Look how many "Run for the Cure" races there are around the world.... It is deceiving to use the word cured and sets people up for unreal expectations for the future. Yes, we all know someone who had breast cancer and died of something else. Like someone with heart disease being hit by a truck. They didn't die of their serious disease, but of something else.. I can attest to the fact that treatment is no guarantee you will stay cancer free.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2016 02:36AM - edited Apr 15, 2016 02:37AM by barbe1958 Just say no. The reason for the number of zaps is due to the "life cycle" of the cancer and them wanting to destroy any growth as/if it occurs. I asked. Stopping for 5 days is scary, but hey! I had to not come in on Good Friday at Easter. The cells would be zapped again when I went back 3 days later.... I do want to add for anyone new here: Aloe of ANY kind is "just to soothe" the skin and not moisturize!! In fact, it will dry out your skin. You must, must, must moisturize heavily with a quality product. I'm getting 9,500 gys and the "normal" is 5-6,000. They kept warning me that I was going to have bad skin damage. I have 7 zaps left and I know it gets worse before it begins to heal, but my skin is just tanned. Not even red. I started to get itchy and immediately got a prescription of hydrocortisone and my skin is not itchy anymore. I'm pleased to say the least and hope I didn't just jinx myself! I had a new tech this morning and she was amazed at my skin. I told her I wasn't bathing every day and was using Glaxol Base. She gave me a thumbs up and said "I can't believe years ago we told people to use Aloe and cornstarch!" I see both mentioned above in the TIPS and am worried for others. Perhaps that is "old" thinking???? My heart goes out to those of you with breasts still as I can imagine heat is trapped under the bra-line and gets irritated under there. Congrats to those who have finished!!!!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 03:46PM barbe1958 wrote: I tried a lumpectomy first and the margins weren't clear so I said to take both off. My tumour was on my chest wall at 6 o'clock on my left breast and I couldn't fool around with rads. If I had just one off, I would have had reconstruction but am glad I didn't. I hear of women saying it takes 1-2 YEARS to complete reconstruction and I just didn't have that down time of repeat surgeries, infections, encapsulations, tatoos, revisions, etc, etc. So I had a double mastectomy and was off work for 2 1/2 weeks. Didn't hurt as much as I was prepared for. As there are no bones, muscles or organs involved, it's really just the wound itself you have to recover from. Good luck in your decision. I was 50 at the time.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 08:23AM - edited Mar 30, 2009 04:33AM by barbe1958 Laurie, it was surreal for me but I'd had years of problems with them and when the cancer finally hit I learned to hate them. Having said that, I did touch, feel and look at them a fair bit before they were gone forever. Just before surgery your surgeon will draw all over them with a marker and that kind of violates them too. In the operating room as they were strapping my arms down I started to cry. It was really going to happen! They were very nice to me and someone touched me until I was under. After, I'd get ripples of anxiety go through my body reminding me about the permanence of the surgery. I could be driving, watching TV, anything. I'd get this little "yikes" shoot through me. But, I have to tell you, the emotion isn't nearly as bad as hearing CANCER. Without immediate reconstruction (none for me anyway) the healing was ridiculously easy! And with good weather coming up where you can get out and about you will be amazed at how quickly you feel good. Right now, part of what you're feeling is because the CANCER is still in there! It really poisons you....  I am now 3 months out and have absolutely no panic about it all. Just fashion challenges that I have really taken to heart. I find it so important to dress prettier than I did before to difuse the flat chest. It's working and I've never regretted a second of my choice. I'm able to tell people I no longer have cancer in my breasts!

BUT, I am down to single digits!! Only 8 more to go.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2009 11:49AM - edited Feb 21, 2009 11:50AM by barbe1958 I am thrilled with how quickly my body bounced back after the surgery and have opted to not have a reconstruction due to the FM. I can't take a chance that it throws me down. My longest time incapacitated was 3 months. I prayed to die during that time as my doctor at that time didn't believe in pain meds and thought it was all in my head. Even the sheets touching my legs was excrutiating! No one who doesn't have it can possibly understand. Doctors are getting much better at pre-treating FM patients. Once I couldn't get out of the recovery room because my blood pressure was too high due to pain. I told them to give me a pain shot but they said that once they did that I would have to stay in recovery for a certain period of time. A vicious circle. You have to stay "above" your pain because once you are in pain, it is too late. I was on Oxycodone for 9 months for 3 herniated disks and one bulging one. It was the narcotic equivalent of 25 Percocets a day! (And I continued to work!) They thought I would have to be hospitalized when I finally got off them, but I didn't. Without the pain, I needed need, or want them! Please make sure who ever is treating you is sympathetic to your situation. Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Fibromyalgia = Pain barbe1958 barbe1958

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 10:01PM barbe1958 wrote: 3 weels post-op isn't very long. "They" say you need a month for every hour you were under. Having said that, FM does cause extreme fatigue. On my days off, I will wake up at 10 am (after going to bed at 9 the night before), have breakfast, do one chore, come home and have a nap until 4 or so. Then back in bed at 9. I have actually used a wheel chair in Costco as I was too exhausted to walk around. My husband just takes one look at me and knows. I can't even get out of the car sometimes and he goes in and does what we need. There have been times in the past that I have crawled to bed on my hands and knees. I was looking for a mother-of-the-bride dress just last month and couldn't even move the dresses aside on the hangers! I had to rest after one or two! Scary stuff...  Fibromyalgia is a very serious disorder and cannot be taken lightly. You get flares just like with MS and lupus. If you don't take care of yourself you can get very, very ill. I was told it was "all in my head" for years until my GP (not anymore!) admitted I had FM. I was furious! My quality of life at that point had me in an electric scooter! It took a long time to get my body back into a functioning mode. I had kept pushing and pushing myself until I literally had a physical breakdown. See your doctor if it continues or gets worse. Google fibromyalgia and read up. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2016 08:35PM barbe1958 wrote: I didn't have recon and started to massage my chest after week one with this small battery operated bug-like thing with wooden legs. Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2016 09:51AM barbe1958 wrote: Scared, the tech may have seen degenerating discs or signs of arthritis. I've had injections both ways, too, so I don't read anything into it anymore. I had a bone scan that lasted an hour and twenty minutes!! They actually let me up to go pee. That freaked me out. Then I've had many scans that go in for better shots and the last one this February had me sit on a chair and put my arms and hands on the scan bed!!! I know breast cancer doesn't go down an arm so I figured it was something else. I found out I have arthritis in every joint in my body including fingers and toes!!! I KNEW I was in pain!!! I've had CT's where they say "that may or may not be real". Go figure. So a repeat scan will often have a slightly better view and discount the first one. For instance, my last CT showed a thickening in my frontal lobe that may or may not be real. As well, a thickening of my colon which may or may not be real. I just had a colonoscopy to see if the colon issue is "real" or not. Oh, what we have to deal with...sigh. We get your fear. Trust me. We've had the other shoe drop and we know it will drop for others. This may sound weird, but I was kind of relieved when my other shoe finally dropped as the 8 years it took to recur were scary ones. Like you're going through right now. I just knew I was going to recur and finally did. It was easier to deal with than I thought. Now I know I'll be watched like a hawk.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 12:53PM barbe1958 wrote: Here's a couple thoughts. Do you wear an underwire? Over the years you will get a build-up where the wire sits (usually if you're heavy breasted, though). Does the mass change with your periods? I once had a huge mass that started to make me unable to life my left arm! The doctor told me if it was cancer, I'd be dead by then. Food for thought. Cancer won't spread into your shoulder as you don't have breast tissue in your shoulder, so you can let that one go. It would go to bones, liver or brain first. 80% of lumps that THEY TAKE OUT are benign. You can imagine the odds on the ones they leave in! Do you drink coffee? It can cause breast lumps. May 3rd isn't that far off. Try to live for now. If it's all clear, you'll be annoyed that you ruined April.......if it's not okay, then at least you had a good April!!! Now go out there and LIVE!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2016 07:58AM barbe1958 wrote: Houston, didn't your supervisors wife want to try the mushrooms? Personally, I trust proven medicine but supplement with minerals like Magnesium and vitamins like B12. When my oral chemo stops working and I get progression, I will move on to an IV chemo until those no longer work for me. It depends where the mets are in your body as to how you can live "normally". If brain mets, you'd have different issues than with say, bone mets. We are surviving longer with current meds, but even diseases like diabetes and heart disease cause death still. The body can only take so much of a treatment before it begins to break down and you have new issues. Some chemos cause heart disease for example. Starting new unproven treatments is difficult to accept unless it's a last resort. Doing so is like going back 40 years when it was all experimental. There are now proven treatments but remember, there is no cure for stage IV.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 08:56AM barbe1958 wrote: I'm glad someone else mentioned Fibromyalgia first as not a lot of people realize how serious it is. I've been following your thread from the beginning and thinking FM. You may have BC as well, but those symtoms are screaming FM! The sternum pain, I used to call my "soul". I come home from work and tell DH that I was exhausted to my soul. I was actually on an electric scooter then cane as I had to work to get over weakness and pain. I still have my electric scooter and don't want to part with it yet. FM is totally debilitating! I have been bedridden so bad that my DH will put Tylenol 3's in my mouth and I can chew and swallow them without lifting my head! The agony of even a bedsheet on me can send my pain level over the moon! I am on some pretty heavy narcotics for the past number of years so I can even get to work (my DH has 3 brain tumours, someone has to pay the mortgage!).  FM is one of the reasons I didn't get a reconstruction after my bilat mx. My docs and I were thrilled with how well I handled the surgery and didn't want to push my luck.  What do I do to survive? Sleep. Rest. Read novels. Sleep. Rest. Read novels. On my days off I will sleep 14-18 hours alone. I give everything I have to getting up to go to work in the morning. I pour myself into my commission job and then come home and drop like a ton of bricks. Sometimes my DH has to help me out of my car to get in the house. He cooks and we eat at TV trays because once I have sat down I can't move around. I have to take narcotics early enough that I can have a shower on the days I shower (not every day).  I have been diagnosed for about 11-12 years now. I have had to learn by trial and error what my body can handle. For example, something like Disneyland would be WAY too much! Even movies aren't really good for me. Too much stimulus is bad for FM. Sleep is the best thing you can do.  You will not always be "bad". You will get flares just like MS. It comes and goes. But, if you are under stress, like you are right now, it's a constant. Because I am under financial pressure, my FM is pretty constant. It's funny our perspective. People want to win the lottery so they can buy a big house or whatever. I want to win the lottery so I can give my body a break and maybe be pain-free! Good luck on whichever way it goes. If God takes you to it, He'll take you through it!

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 08:25AM barbe1958 wrote: Though I was finally glad to have the diagnosis of Fibromyalgia (so I didn't have to feel crazy anymore) I find it harder to deal with than my cancer! It CAN be debilitating, but doesn't HAVE to be if/when you learn just how much your body can take. You are doing the right thing by staying on top of your pain. Don't be disappointed if the bone scan doesn't show anything...I know that sounds weird to say. Everytime I had a test and they said "nothing" I felt like it was all in my head! Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2016 06:33PM barbe1958 wrote: I believe I benefited from my "treatment". Bilat mast no recon with no chemo and no rads. No Tamoxifen and no AI. Gershwin isn't a typo from me, it's what the person called it...hehehe The one supplement I've found that has pretty much saved my life is Magnesium. Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 07:16AM barbe1958 wrote: I had a breast reduction years ago due to arthritis in my neck causing bone spurs to grow into the back of my throat. I HATED my breasts for causing that agony! With the surgery I had beautiful perky breasts for a 50 year old, but they never felt like mine again. It took a year for me to get sensation back in one of the nipples. So having no weight on my chest has been a Godsend. When I've had my scares (2 lumpectomies and 2 additional biopsies) I knew I'd never get recon. I have other health issues and to put myself into yet more surgery was not smart. I did not want to focus anymore attention on my breasts. They'd taken up enough of my life. I was 38D in grade 9. Not having to worry about clothing issues and gaping buttons has been wonderful! I feel much slimmer and move and stand way better as well. I looked at a LOT of pictures on a LOT of websites and didn't like the scarring I saw with the surgeries. To me, it wasn't worth keeping the breasts just to have bumps in my clothes if they weren't going to look good naked. I am not that concerned about body image at 52, but still dress girly with make-up and jewelry and stuff. Just no boobs. I needed, had to, get back to work as quickly as possible due to financial issues and the quickest way was mast. As I'd already had 2 surgeries on my right breast - the non-cancer side - I said take them both off. Now I'm not lop-sided weight wise, so my neck is fine. I sweat enough as it is without a heavy gel form. My breasts were a 42D so my form would be awfully big. I have been VERY comfortable with my decision and the first time I have felt even a bit sad is when I consider holding my new grandchild in September in my arms and not have the bosom to cuddle him with.....sigh.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2014 11:21PM barbe1958 wrote: sparkle, the wait-and-see option is to see if the lump has grown. Breast cancer normally doubles in size every 180 days...normally. So if you go back in 6+ months they can see if the lump has grown. Some lumps ARE too small to biopsy. We understand your fear. I had my first lumpectomy when I was 21!! The tumour was so big the surgeon said I would have been dead if it was breast cancer. You are wise to keep an eye on the lump, but rest assured that they will take you very seriously if they see something in your next set of tests and scans. We grow lumps in our breasts for so many reasons - hormonal, caffeine, hereditary, etc that they just can't jump onto every lump they find. Good luck, sweetie! (Less than 10-15% of all breast cancer is hereditary so that is a dumb excuse on the doctor's part!!)

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 10:49AM barbe1958 wrote: If the tumour is actually more than a cm or 3, they may want to do chemo first to shrink it to make the surgery less invasive. If it can be shrunk enough, she may get away with just a lumpectomy where they take part of her breast away with the tumour. It may seem backwards but it is actually a better surgical outcome, depending on where the tumour is sitting. Mine was sitting right on my chest wall and was only 1 cm so I tried for a lumpectomy. He couldn't get clear margins - meaning that there was still cancer cells right to the edge of the tissue he took out. There is always the fear that those cells go even further, so I chose a mastectomy. I didn't want to go through more surgery for reconstruction so I had both breasts removed. I'd already had a tumour removed from my right breast anyway and the patholgoy showed I was only months away from a developed cancer there anyway!!!! In fact, they were more worried abou my right breast and the cancer was actually in my left! The PET (wow!! I can't get a PET in Ontario) or CT scan is to make sure there isn't obvious cancer anywhere else in her body. If so, they would treat with chemo until she showed NED (No Evidence of Disease) and then maybe, consider surgery or not. It can also check her nodes to see if any have to come out with the surgery. There is a fear when they go to get the tumour as certain things can happen. Even the biopsy can lead to 'seeding' where the needle actually pulls cancer cells through normal breast tissue and deposits them to the breast on the way out! When they do a lumpectomy, the surge of oxygen that the tumour gets causes it to grow drastically. That is why you have to move quickly once you've pissed off the tumour. Having the chemo first can kill off any nodal issues as wel as shrink the tumour. After surgery, she'd probably get rads to kill off any stray cells that remained. All in all, it's a normal process for the medical team - just not for you guys! It's new and scary, make sure you like your team or ask for another. You have the right to be comfortable with the people that literally are holding your mom's life in their hands. Keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2016 06:33PM barbe1958 wrote: I take a full Hydrochorothyazide every day and Avapro. It took a YEAR to find this balance for my blood pressure. See a Nephrologist if you can to get it settled down. I've been on BP meds for 25 years now and occasional had to get the meds changed but once I saw the specialist it's been good. It took a long time for it to be "right" but I only take 2 pills a day for BP. The other 14 I take are for other issues...sigh. It seemed that everytime I saw a doc I had to double my BP meds until I put my foot down and said no way. They sent me to the specialist and he worked with me month after month until I got balanced. You have to give the meds a chance to build up in your system and then when you change them, you have to get the old ones out of your system to give the new ones a chance. Frustrating for sure! Good luck, sweetie.

Posts.Title: Hugs From Yan barbe1958 Chevyboy

Posts.Content: barbe1958 wrote: It was a beautiful, crisp sunny day as DH and I drove to Yan's house, just north of Toronto. The area had newer houses, many showing signs of young families inside with basketball hoops and bikes at garage doors, and there was still some snow in the shaded areas. As we stepped onto the porch, the door was opened by someone on a cell phone. We removed our shoes, noticing the mirror in the hallway was covered. As we entered the main living area I noted the beautifully coloured walls and tons and tons of pictures of Olga and her young famliy all around. I turned to meet Yan as he came into the room. Our eyes met and I saw as he recognized me from the boards here. I opened my arms and we hugged as I started to cry. "She's everywhere", he said and we hugged some more. "There is so much love pouring out for you and your family" I assured him. "There is pain and grief for Olga and so much support for you and the boys." I was introduced to Olga's Mom and she began to cry too as I hugged her. How can a mother see her own child pass before her? I cannot imagine her pain. Her Dad and brother were there as well, and a cousin of Yan's as well as his Dad. The boys were upstairs making boy noises, which added some levity as they played their games. There was a communication issue as Olga's family only spoke Hebrew, but grief is international and we sat in mutual pain as Yan spoke of Olga's last days. He told us how peaceful she was at the end, slipping from breath to no-breath without any pain. He told us how the older boy was being seen by someone at the school who had prepared him for his Mom's death; how calm the boy was as it was happening, and the letdown of grief when it was all over. Yan didn't have the boys at the hospital while Olga was in such pain as he didn't want them to remember her that way. He couldn't imagine having her pass at home as the memories would be so hard to bear. "It was pretty bad at times," he said, "She was in a lot of pain before they got it under control." His eyes showed his pain and we shared more tears. Then it hit me that I felt guilty. My kids were grown up and had kids of their own! His sons were still so young (9 & 5) and Olga should have had more time with them, just as they should have had their Mom longer. I was sitting there with Yan, where Olga should have been and I felt so bad. I began to cry harder and Yan, bless his heart, tried to comfort ME. That's when I knew we should leave. I went to comfort Yan in his time of need, not to have him need to comfort me. As we had a final hug, he told me to pass this hug on to everyone, so I told him to make it a good one. He did, and I am passing it on. I got a hug from a strong and loving man who just lost the love of his life. His compassion for us here was very evident and he will be back to let us know how they are doing. God Bless you Yan, and your boys. May you find peace in the days to come. With love, Barbara Dx 12/10/2008, IDC: Papillary, Left, 1cm, Stage IB, 2/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/16/2008 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Dx 2/4/2016, IDC: Papillary, Left, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 2/11/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole) Radiation Therapy 2/17/2016 Whole-breast: Lymph nodes, Chest wall Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 10:11AM barbe1958 wrote: I think you maybe need outside help if you are feeling guilty about the amount of support your husband is giving you. You have the right to dump on someone who is neutral to your situation. We try not to talk about the worst case scenarios with our loved ones, but we do need to talk. This site is a God-send, but sometimes it isn't enough. You have the right to grieve the loss of your health. It is part of the acceptance of what is happening to you. I am on antidepressants as I have to keep moving forward. Yesterday for the first time I admitted how much energy I was spending trying to stay positive but I'm afraid if I let myself slip for a second I'll crumble into a pile of mush. Find a therapist, support group or just talk to your doctor. You can't do this alone, no one expects you to. If you have a higher power, reach out and grab his/her hand and tell them you need them. NOW! You are in my prayers. And I have a strong God that I will share with you!

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 12:51PM - edited Mar 13, 2009 01:00PM by barbe1958 I have read this thread with much admiration for you ladies. I have chosen to go flat. I mean flat. No recon, no foobies. I went from a 42D to nothing. I am not a small lady, size 14-16 and still carry some weight around my ribcage (previous ballast for large breasts). I don't know of anyone who has gone totally flat; I had no role models. My work knew I was getting them off; and as I told one co-worker before I had surgery, "Why should I wear fake breasts to make YOU feel more comfortable?"! The public didn't know (I'm in sales), but have been polite enough to not say anything. I wear cute cropped sweaters or something so from the side it is not obvious. What is anyone going to say anyway? It's kind of obvious... I have had a lot of flack from other sites who acuse me of wanting to be a poster child and that I'm not normal. They say breasts are about being a woman. I have felt so frustrated until I came upon this thread. I am not ashamed of my cancer. I can't forget it every day so why should I "primp" and "preen" just to make the general public think everything is okay? It isn't! I have embraced my flatness. I look thinner and clothes fit a lot better. I carry my flat chest as a shield and unlike some of you ladies, no one has cared to ask. I'm sure they'd know if they were really checking me out. I don't feel like I have to explain anything, but wouldn't feel badly if I had to.  I didn't flaunt my breasts and now I don't flaunt my flatness. It just IS. I carry myself with the same grace and elegance as when I had breasts. I am still me. I am still woman, hear me roar! Thank you for an inspiring thread!

I can't get an MRI due to a pacemaker so had a CT which did show a thickening in my frontal lobe but we already knew that. It also showed what might be the beginning of an aneurism. A CT Angiography was recommended which I did. After the CT I was so bad I went directly to the ER. They figured it was an inner ear issue and put me on a medication for tinitis that acutally worked. It took about a week but it finally began to resolve. Fortunately the pending aneurism turned out okay as well. I was so sick and had just started a new job as well. I had to take 2 1/2 days off my first week at work! I did bring them a letter from the ER to cover my butt. It said to take off a week, but I just took off 3 more days. I was sweaty and disoriented at work and bouncing off the walls at home. I even introduced myself to someone at work by saying, "Hi, my name is Paul." Can you imagine my fear? I've had a couple of "black out" kind of moments - watching TV for example and finding a fresh cup of tea in front of me and my DH saying he just brought it. Really? He paused the show, left the room and brought in tea....I had no idea. I was doing a jigsaw puzzle on my laptop but I wasn't that involved! I found if I went into a dark room at night I was totally disoriented - couldn't tell up from down. I stubbed my toes so many times I had a black toe on one foot or the other for weeks. So I'm still not sure what to do and I totally understand your fear. Please let us know what they are recommending and I pray for a clear study for you.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2011 11:20AM barbe1958 wrote: Jen, we have the technology and you have the right to it! The very fact that you are questioning taking anything shows that you are open to the help it can give you. As Diana says, it may take a couple of tries before you get the right one for your needs. Some make you feel really dopey at the beginning, but that goes away as your body gets used to it. It can take up to 6 weeks to be solid in your system. You will have to decide if you need relief from stress, anxiety, overwhelmed feeling, depression, fatigue, etc as each pill works in different ways. Don't give up if the first one doesn't cut it. It's a bit of a hassle working it out, but once in place is literally a life saver. For your daughters and you. I have been on some kind of anti-anxiety med for over 30 years as my body is missing the chemical that others have naturally. It's not my fault and I am mature enough to accept the fact that for me, it's a maintenance drug, just like a diabetic has to deal with. You should not feel 'high' or even know there is a drug in your system, but at first you may think it's too much to deal with. Try to ease onto something over a long-weekend (July 4th?) so you are used to it before you have to drive to work. Let your daughters know what you are doing so they understand that you are taking responsibility for your part in the stress. If you want to move off the farm, do it!! The kids are too young to help you effectively, and probably don't want their weekends taken up with chores! They'll get over it, if you move into a cute little town house. They've had the farm experience. It's time for YOU and your needs. That's part of your stress, worrying about the effects on them. Of course if affects them! Anything would, even good news.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 09:53AM barbe1958 wrote: Connie, if  you're not getting recon, you will find it surprisingly not as painful as your brain is thinking it will be. As there is no muscles, bones or organs involved, the healing is fairly quick and painless. I have a very LOW tolerance for pain and didn't even take a prescription pain med home! When the nerves started to regenerate about 1 week to 10 days in, that was the most annoying time of zapping on my chest wall. The drains are a hassle, but very do-able. You don't want to have to reach UP or DOWN for anything for a couple of weeks. Have your hair done at a salon or over the kitchen sink. I put a TV tray further down my bed than my night table so I didn't have to reach up, just over. You will use your abs and legs to get in and out of bed instead of your arms. Get lots of good books and/or videos and don't lift anything over 5 pounds. Seriously. You have inner stitches you don't want to tear!! Don't try to be a hero - SLEEP and NAP as often as you can as you heal while asleep. You have to get over the anaesthetic too! Build a nest of pillows around you wherever you are so that you don't turn or move the wrong way. You won't be able to drive for a couple of weeks as you use a surprising amount of chest muscles when driving. Practice in your driveway first so you see what I mean. When you turn to look behind you, you will be tugging on your chest muscles. You might also want to make or get a little pillow for the seat belt as it tugs across your chest as well. Have soft sily nighties so they'll slide easier in bed and feel good on your chest.  Good luck, sweetie! Feel free to PM me if you need more answers.
Posts.Title: bi-lateral in 2 weeks lost in sea of posts of what I need ConnieGreene exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 01:11PM barbe1958 wrote: Jenifer, some hospitals in the USA would do masts as day surgery! You are sometimes in longer with different reconstructions. It's important to note in your posts whether you are having recon as that makes it a longer and more painful recovery. You should be able to wipe yourself, but doing your hair is hard - your hands over your head is difficult in the beginning.  It was my idea of the silky pj's, thanks. You will find you have to use your legs and ab muscles you didn't even know you had to get in and out of bed. You can't push down on your arms (you won't want to!! ). Slippery also helps you adjust in bed without using your arms. I used a zip-up hoodie with pockets for my drains and my housecoat pockets when in pjs. At night, I laid the drains out carefully on the pillows by my side so I knew where they were when I woke up. You will NOT be tossing and turning while the drains are in - trust me!!  Someone above mentioned rubber gloves for the drains but that wouldn't work without using something jelly or slippery-like on the drains as well. You have to run your fingers down the plastic tubing to get the gunk moved into the drain, so if you use rubber gloves they won't slide. Drains are only in for a short time, so don't invest a lot of dollars in their use!!!!

Posts.Title: I'm so angry; I did not ask my radiologist the right questions. GraceBer barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 02:50AM barbe1958 wrote: I'm surprised they will be able to tell you your results "immediately"!!!! They may come back undetermined and need further testing - mine took about 10 days. The radiologist won't necessarily have the best bedside manner, either, so be prepared. Knowledge IS power and the more you know the more prepared you'll be, but please know that 80% of BIOPSIED lumps are benign!!!!! That means there are a TON of women without cancer walking around. They only biopsy suspicious lumps or ones they can't definitely determine by shape, size, etc. They may make you wait for another period cycle as well...I'm fortunate that I'd had a hysterectomy, as they were going to wait another month for more testing. Cysts react to your hormones during your cycle and they might want to see what happens. If they tell you to wait for 3 months to be re-tested don't panic. If your lump grows fast, they'd take you in sooner, but breast cancer doubles in size every 180 days (3 months) and that would be another indicator. A lot of cancer has been growing in a breast for 8-10 years before it is big enough to be felt or show up on imaging. The most frustrating thing you'll hear is the "watch-and-wait" I mentioned as you'll be chewing your guts out for 3 months!! An appointment with a breast surgeon would be most appropriate as you'd want one to see "normal" results if this lump turns out benign. If cancerous, you've already started the process. We have blazed the trail before you, so please know you are not alone and we TRULY understand your fears, panic modes, denial, promises to God and all those feelings you are having right now. Keep us updated here so we can know how you are doing. Good luck sweetie!!
Posts.Title: I'm so angry; I did not ask my radiologist the right questions. GraceBer barbe1958

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 02:29PM barbe1958 wrote: We have a number of hospitals in Toronto (Ontario) that give immediate results, but at the time, my local hospital wasn't a "Cancer Centre" though it did provide surgery, chemo and rads. I wonder if it gives immediate results now.... My cancer is very, very rare (less than 2% of all breast cancers) called Papillary Carcinoma. I used to have it on my tag line, but so many newbies thought it was a papilloma and they panicked!! I figured my sample needed extra time due to the rareness of it. I didn't want it to be undetermined so I appreciated the diligence. I've read of women getting a benign for nodes during surgery with immediate checking and then be told afterwards that they found cells on further investigation. I wasn't allowed my DH to be with me during my biopsy (the gun that shoots a needle into the mass!!!). The bruising was truly spectacular!! The entire lower half of my breast was BLACK. He was allowed in for a thyroid biopsy - FNA - years earlier. It was a gentle process where the worst was when they said "don't move or swallow". They took 13 attempts and he hit the wall and slid to the floor at about number five!!! They had warned him they wouldn't help him and they didn't!!! I can't imagine how he would have done with the "nail gun" on my breast..hehehehehhehehe There is a saying: The best lump is a lump in a jar! If it doesn't belong in my body - GET IT OUT!!!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 02:58PM barbe1958 wrote: It becomes a fine line when you have befriended someone in a different thread...let's say "Middle Age" thread and it doesn't matter in that thread what stage they are - we are all just women with breast cancer. I have done it for both my parents with my brothers and sister there as well. We all knew why we were there and it is not a pleasant place to be.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2016 10:27AM barbe1958 wrote: Interestingly enough, I sort of "left" bco in November of 2014 when I moved. Then I started a job which I loved - BUT - last July I got a new boss who hated me. Seriously. She rode me day after day and I would go into my office and cry. I didn't even cry when my parents died, or when I was diagnosed with cancer! Then in October I felt a new lump. I've had a biopsy and lumpectomy which is positive for breast cancer but I don't have the markers in yet. I had a CT and bone scan this week and will see the surgeon on Tuesday and new onc on Thursday to set up a plan. I had a double mast the first time without any further treatment. I've been 7 years "cancer free". So. Did the stress of the new boss and/or lack of bco support change my body chemistry? If I'd had chemo and/or rads the first time, we'd be saying "hey I had a good 7 year run, I'll take it". But I got the 7 years without any treatment except surgery. This time I can do the chemo and/or rads I didn't do the first time. Sadly I kind of made a "deal" with God that if I stayed cancer-free I'd stop drinking. Two of my kids got married and I toasted them with ginger ale. Then by September I was so stressed with my horrid boss that I started having a glass or two of wine occasionally. Did breaking my "deal" with God cause my new cancer???? So just how much does our thoughts create - help - stop - change our body. They say what you think you are, you are. Now I have to think of myself as a fighter. She fired me 3 days before I got the diagnosis (she knew I was getting it). After all, wouldn't she be a real bitch if she fired me AFTER learning that my cancer returned?

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 10:32AM barbe1958 wrote: Amy, there is a reason of when during your cycle to check for lumps as at certain points ANY parts of your breast may be sore! Also, common cysts react to your hormones during your period and swell or hurt. Don't knock yourself out for what you "may have" missed. Cancer lives in our breasts for many years before it is big enough to be picked up by technology. You don't really want to skip the imaging, you want to skip the diagnosis!! We GET it. We know exactly how you feel!! Your girlfriends and husband won't get it the same way we do. There is an area of your breast where the underwire of your bra ends, pretty much at the site you speak of. Your skin can build up underneath that to protect the area. It may all be as simple as that. Your doc would not have been doing her job if she didn't pursue ANY lump or mass she found. We are here for you, please let us know how it all goes!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2009 09:34AM - edited Feb 8, 2009 09:35AM by barbe1958 This is the time that you truly learn to "live in the moment". I never really understand that fully until now. I also think a sense of humour helps. Remember, your body runs on chemicals. Your brain can be either over or underloaded on important ones. That is why you may need a chemical intervention. You do it for cancer, don't you? I find my Zoloft keeps my anger at bay and my Welbutrin keeps me upbeat. Of course I have horrid things happen to me, but I deal with them much more positively when my brain isn't dragging me down. I don't feel drugged or medicated at all so I'm not over-prescribed on it. It takes time to hit your system and experimentation to adjust the dose for balance. You have the right for help. It comes in a bottle and no one has to know. (and it's not alcohol! LOL)

Posts.Content: May 2, 2013 05:07PM barbe1958 wrote: Maria, I got a double mast with NO reconstruction. As an athlete, you may enjoy the flatter, sleeker look. I am not an athlete, but without breasts I look slimmer. I have people say they notice I've lost weight and I say nothing! If you are concerned about your body, you might want to seriously consider whether ANY implants are right for you! There are a lot of things that go wrong during surgery and many women end up with what they call "a tight band around my chest" as the surgeons have to tighten all your chest muscles to hold up your implant. No thanks! As for risk, my tumour was over my heart (and lung) at 6 o'clock on my left breast. I didn't even consider RADS!! Both my cardiologist and PCP have said thank God I didn't do rads! My tumour was 1 cm, the size of your baby fingernail. By removing the tumour with the breast tissue there was nothing left to radiate and as it was a small tumour (1 cm) there was no more need for rads. There was no way I was going to risk my heart and left lung for a 2% drop in recurrence! I've said before that it would have to be a 25-30% reduction in risk for me to take on rads. Say your recurrence rate was 10%. Say someone told you that rads reduces your rate by half. That's not 50%. That's 1/2 of 10%, which means your recurrence rate has dropped to 5%. So you can still get a recurrence! So can I. Odds are just numbers and we have both already beaten the odds by getting cancer in the first place. Maybe we've had our dose of crap and there's no more to come. Maybe there is.... NO ONE can tell you what is the right thing to do. Only YOU can figure it out which is why your docs are sitting back. No one wants to say do it and then you get lung damage. Please read the threads on pumonary issues!!!! No one wants to say don't do it and then you get a recurrence!!  It's kind of like being Clint Eastwood...."Are you feeling lucky today?"

I wanted to take glucosamine when it first came out and happened to mention it to my doc. He said NO! Not that they're bad, but your doctor HAS to know what you're taking as it does affect your blood. People list aspirins and cold remedies to their docs, but forget vitamins and other stuff like flax, fish oil, etc.

Posts.Content: barbe1958 wrote: For those of you without first hand knowledge, FM (fibromyalgia) can cause you to sense way more pain than someone else. I have been readings posts tonight from members who can't believe how much pain they are still in and feeling depressed and guilty. With FM you have to take the pain meds BEFORE you feel the pain, as once you have reached a certain level, nothing will get the pain down. More doctors are aware of this disorder and I often get pain meds before surgery even starts. I make sure that anyone dealing with me during a procedure understands what FM does to my sensation of pain. I do not have a low pain thresh-hold, I have FM. It has been a deblitating cross to bear over the last 10 years or so, and I was terrified that the stress on my body and mind would put me into a "flare" with the surgery. By being proactive, I was able to maintain control over my whole healing process and am very proud of myself. For those of you who aren't sure if you have FM, PLEASE Google it!  Dx 12/10/2008, IDC: Papillary, Left, 1cm, Stage IB, 2/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/16/2008 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Dx 2/4/2016, IDC: Papillary, Left, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 2/11/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole) Radiation Therapy 2/17/2016 Whole-breast: Lymph nodes, Chest wall Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 26, 2014 06:55AM barbe1958 wrote: Pica, I want to respond as you've been waiting so long for an answer and this will bump your post higher up the list. I had an ultrasound guided biopsy and my tumour was very close to my chest wall, too. The radiologist who does the biopsy does NOT want to go through the tumour as that would be pointless - they wouldn't get any sample tissue. So they judge very carefully how deep to go - sometimes making a number of attempts to judge it, so be prepared for more than one poke. Perhaps an MRI guided biopsy is more precise, but I watched on the US screen as my doctor shot a needle (from a gun thingy) into the tumour exactly! It grabbed a piece of tissue and brought it back out. Fascinating. I don't know how much you'll be able to watch, but it was cool seeing the lump they were after. It was totally black on the US monitor. I don't know the process you'll be getting, whether a gun or hand-held needle but they do not want to mess around, so trust the process. If they don't think they got a good sample, as I said, they'll go in again. Sometimes, rarely they burst a cyst that they thought was solid, so don't be surprised. I've had 4 biopsies over 29 years and one lump got burst that way so they knew it wasn't cancer. Good luck, sweetie!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 10:24AM barbe1958 wrote: The fact that you feel he cheated is what counts. You've had some good advice with the posts above, but as some have said, it's what YOU feel that matters. It is a violation of your marriage vows and  you may be wondering if he admits to the strip-clubs, what ISN'T he telling you? On the other hand, you have been married for 20 years, do you really know this man? CAN you trust him again? If not, it's not fair to you or him to continue in the relationship as it would just be an unhealthy relationship of worrying, wondering and watching. IF you can put aside the feeling of being cheated on (I say "feeling" as he didn't physically cheat on you) then you may be able to rescue the relationship. DO you want to rescue it? Or is this a signal for a break? IS it worth saving? Porn aside, WAS it a good marriage? You don't say in your post. As someone said, would he have told you?? It makes HIM feel better to get it off his chest, but makes YOU feel worse!! Is he flaunting the fact that "at least he told you"? Doed the counsellor see the real picture?  Your marriage couldn't have been all bad, or you would have jumped all over this as an opportunity to leave with dignity. Do the good times out-weigh the bad ones? Only YOU can call the shots right now. He has lost the right to an opinion on this. Good luck, sweetie!

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2012 12:33PM barbe1958 wrote: Bob, once she is opened up and the tumour exposed to air (oxygen rich) that is when the speed factor comes into play. So if she doesn't get clear margins (no cancer near the edges of what is taken out) then the second surgery should be done quickly. That was my six day wait. Lumpectomy showed cancer but not clear margins so they had to go in again anyway. (Needle biopsy had been "worrisome for cancer" but inconclusive.) Lumpectomy showed a very rare breast cancer, Papillary Carcinoma, but with cancer in the margins. You will be a doctor by the time you finish all this with your wife. But knowledge is power. Keep reading!

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 05:07AM barbe1958 wrote: While I was still healing from my mast, I went through my closet and got rid of my Boob Tops. The ones that had darts, plunging necklines, would sag with too much fabric without boobs, etc. It was very cathartic. Some were very expensive, some not so much. I gave the huge green garbage bag to my DD and DIL to go through so I knew at least some would get used by family. I gave my hairdresser a couple of my favourites from over the years. As I throw NOTHING out, it was quite a packed bag, well over-due in purging. Then I got to shop. It was actually quite painful at times to lift my arms over my head and manouver out of some types of tops. Twice I was almost in tears in the change room when I realized that I couldn't get the top off! I learned to pull the bottom hem up and over my head by leaning my head between my knees as I sat down. I felt NO guilt when I brought my purchases home and would model them for my DH. I let him feel how soft the fabrics were and made him a part of the decisions. I think it helped him a lot too, to see me so happy with a new top for my flat chest! I'm sure Ed is pleased as puch for Cathi that she has found so many bathing suits, it wasn't a good Spring for her as she dreaded the purchasing process. Good luck to everyone! As Stacy and Clinton say "JUST TRY IT ON"! You'l be surprised!

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 07:46AM barbe1958 wrote: Because there is no muscle, bone or organs involved, it IS surprisingly pain free! I left the hospital without any prescription and I have a very LOW tolerance for pain due to Fibromyalgia. That was my biggest fear, that the pain would knock me for a loop! The most annoying time (besides the SNB site and the drains) was about 10 days out when the nerves started regenerating and it felt like zaps shooting across my chest. A good sign though, so tolerable. If you take too many pain meds, you will hold yourself back. They will tire you out and constipate you. So make sure you take a Sennoket laxative with a stool softener to keep you regular during healing. You do NOT want to deal with that during this time. If you find yourself sleeping too much, it could be the pain meds. A nap is nice though!! You will be able to type immediately, but will find you arm will tire easily. I remember searching for mother-of-the-bride dresses about 2 months out and being surprised that it was hard to "flip" through the heavy gowns on the racks. That is a time line that I remember well. You want to gently stretch out your arm and keep it moving or you could seize up. That is also something you won't want to deal with - frozen shoulder. I remember the first time I woke up with my hand above my head and being really pleased that I didn't wake up due to zaps. You won't need a recliner necessarily. Women who get recon need them. You WILL need to use stomach muscles to get up and down in bed. Swing your legs over the side first, and then sit up. Do the opposite to get in. You will not want to push down on your arm(s) to brace yourself. The biggest thing is to try not to ge scar tissue build-up. I had my DH give me nightly cream rubs (from pharmacy, not beauty centre) across my wound once the steri-strips (instead of stiches) came off. It relieved the itchiness as I healed and got him very used to my new look. You will only want very soft things against your chest forever now. You will find polyester irritating and may have to wear cami's underneath your present clothing to act as a softness between you and scratchy fabrics. Before, your breasts kept clothing tight against your chest. You won't have that now, so you will get gaping like you've never had before! Soft cami's will look very sexy and make you feel pretty, believe it or not! I actually feel sexier now than when I had breasts like everyone else! I use big necklaces or earrings to draw eyes away from my chest. At my present job, I worked with someone for 6 months before I mentioned breast cancer and her jaw literally hit her desk when I mentioned that I didn't have breasts! It does NOT have to be obvious! I wear busy patterened, flowy, ruched, soft tops that aren't tight to my chest. It's not obvious. I went from a full 42D to nothing! Some people mention that it looks like I lost a lot of weight and I just smile! Good luck and please let us know how you are doing!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2016 02:46PM barbe1958 wrote: Another thing we did with my parents dying was touch them and talk to them, so thanks for mentioning that longterm. As they were both unconscious near death, we also "gave them permission" to "go"; telling them they had done good and now it was time for them to move on. We hope it gave them peace. They didn't really want to be touched and pulled away. When they started "picking" at their blankets my sister said that was a classic sign that death was imminent. My Dad said nothing for 2 days and then woke up for 3 seconds and said to my daughter "In 24 hours I'm going up". Freaked her out (she was 23) and I was in the bathroom and missed it. Sure enough he died 24 hours later...... While he was semi-conscious he was really quite funny - asking for Evian water and then saying you know what that is spelled backwards, right? It was like he was trying to entertain us. He kept "smoking" too (no cigarette in his hand) right until the end, almost. I feel guilty that I'll possibly die before my husband! I know it will rip him apart, as would his death do me. Good ole Catholic guilt.......

Posts.Content: May 17, 2016 05:26PM barbe1958 wrote: I've had much shorter experiences in hospice with some friend passing within 3 days of going in. He slipped into unconsciousness on Friday but on Saturday morning he woke up at 6:15 am and told my daughter he was "going up in 24 hours".He died Sunday morning. My Mom went in on a Wednesday and I couldn't get to her until Friday and she was already unconscious pretty much but she did open her eyes when I reached her so I know she knows I was there. She died the following Tuesday. So less than a week.

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2016 12:21PM barbe1958 wrote: I took the liberty of copying some of the pertinent info on that link you posted LongTerm for those who can't activate links: "Failure to thrive" is a broad term for a number of developments in end-stage cancer that basically lead to someone slowing down in a stepwise deterioration until death. Cancer is caused by an uninhibited growth of previously normal cells that expertly evade the body's usual defences to spread, or metastasise, to other parts. When cancer affects a vital organ, its function is impaired and the impairment can result in death. The liver and kidneys eliminate toxins and maintain normal physiology – they're normally organs of great reserve so when they fail, death is imminent. Cancer cells release a plethora of chemicals that inhibit appetite and affect the digestion and absorption of food, leading to progressive weight loss and hence, profound weakness. Dehydration is not uncommon, due to distaste for fluids or an inability to swallow. The lack of nutrition, hydration and activity causes rapid loss of muscle mass and weakness. Metastases to the lung are common and can cause distressing shortness of breath – it's important to understand that the lungs (or other organs) don't stop working altogether, but performing under great stress exhausts them. It's like constantly pushing uphill against a heavy weight. Cancer patients can also die from uncontrolled infection that overwhelms the body's usual resources. Having cancer impairs immunity and recent chemotherapy compounds the problem by suppressing the bone marrow. The bone marrow can be considered the factory where blood cells are produced – its function may be impaired by chemotherapy or infiltration by cancer cells.Death can occur due to a severe infection. Pre-existing liver impairment or kidney failure due to dehydration can make antibiotic choice difficult, too. You may notice that patients with cancer involving their brain look particularly unwell. Most cancers in the brain come from elsewhere, such as the breast, lung and kidney. Brain metastases exert their influence in a few ways – by causing seizures, paralysis, bleeding or behavioural disturbance. Patients affected by brain metastases can become fatigued and uninterested and rapidly grow frail. Swelling in the brain can lead to progressive loss of consciousness and death. In some cancers, such as that of the prostate, breast and lung, bone metastases or biochemical changes can give rise to dangerously high levels of calcium, which causes reduced consciousness and renal failure, leading to death. Uncontrolled bleeding, cardiac arrest or respiratory failure due to a large blood clot happen – but contrary to popular belief, sudden and catastrophic death in cancer is rare. And of course, even patients with advanced cancer can succumb to a heart attack or stroke, common non-cancer causes of mortality in the general community. You may have heard of the so-called "double effect" of giving strong medications such as morphine for cancer pain, fearing that the escalation of the drug levels hastens death. But experts say that opioids are vital to relieving suffering and that they typically don't shorten an already limited life.

Posts.Content: barbe1958 wrote: It was a beautiful, crisp sunny day as DH and I drove to Yan's house, just north of Toronto. The area had newer houses, many showing signs of young families inside with basketball hoops and bikes at garage doors, and there was still some snow in the shaded areas. As we stepped onto the porch, the door was opened by someone on a cell phone. We removed our shoes, noticing the mirror in the hallway was covered. As we entered the main living area I noted the beautifully coloured walls and tons and tons of pictures of Olga and her young famliy all around. I turned to meet Yan as he came into the room. Our eyes met and I saw as he recognized me from the boards here. I opened my arms and we hugged as I started to cry. "She's everywhere", he said and we hugged some more. "There is so much love pouring out for you and your family" I assured him. "There is pain and grief for Olga and so much support for you and the boys." I was introduced to Olga's Mom and she began to cry too as I hugged her. How can a mother see her own child pass before her? I cannot imagine her pain. Her Dad and brother were there as well, and a cousin of Yan's as well as his Dad. The boys were upstairs making boy noises, which added some levity as they played their games. There was a communication issue as Olga's family only spoke Hebrew, but grief is international and we sat in mutual pain as Yan spoke of Olga's last days. He told us how peaceful she was at the end, slipping from breath to no-breath without any pain. He told us how the older boy was being seen by someone at the school who had prepared him for his Mom's death; how calm the boy was as it was happening, and the letdown of grief when it was all over. Yan didn't have the boys at the hospital while Olga was in such pain as he didn't want them to remember her that way. He couldn't imagine having her pass at home as the memories would be so hard to bear. "It was pretty bad at times," he said, "She was in a lot of pain before they got it under control." His eyes showed his pain and we shared more tears. Then it hit me that I felt guilty. My kids were grown up and had kids of their own! His sons were still so young (9 & 5) and Olga should have had more time with them, just as they should have had their Mom longer. I was sitting there with Yan, where Olga should have been and I felt so bad. I began to cry harder and Yan, bless his heart, tried to comfort ME. That's when I knew we should leave. I went to comfort Yan in his time of need, not to have him need to comfort me. As we had a final hug, he told me to pass this hug on to everyone, so I told him to make it a good one. He did, and I am passing it on. I got a hug from a strong and loving man who just lost the love of his life. His compassion for us here was very evident and he will be back to let us know how they are doing. God Bless you Yan, and your boys. May you find peace in the days to come. With love, Barbara Dx 12/10/2008, IDC: Papillary, Left, 1cm, Stage IB, 2/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/16/2008 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Dx 2/4/2016, IDC: Papillary, Left, Stage IV, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 2/11/2016 Arimidex (anastrozole) Radiation Therapy 2/17/2016 Whole-breast: Lymph nodes, Chest wall Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 07:42PM barbe1958 wrote: I had my surgery same time as GryffinSong and we seem to be healing at the same rate! The drains are more of a nuisance and itch, sometimes uncomfortable to lie on and every once in a while you tug on one too hard, but the stitch holds. I am still draining over 50 cc's a day on my left side (SNB) and can't get the last drain out! I really don't want to go into 2009 with a drain in. Crossing my fingers for Tuesday when the nurse comes back. I am not going to wear foobies and have already gleaned my wardrobe of clothing I can wear to work. As everyone at work knows what I have been through, I don't feel I have to wear anything. I have jackets that cover most of my chest and have bought beautiful tanks in gorgeous colours to add a shot of distraction. I'm finding it harder to find casual clothing and am looking for waisted items that can "slouch and puff" across my chest instead of pulling flat. I was a 42D (after a reduction!) and am so thrilled to not have breasts that I think I'm still in denial. I do find that I am fixated with other womens' chests on TV, when before I didn't even notice. I know I'll shed some tears down the road...

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 05:29AM barbe1958 wrote: As a "Sleep Expert", I have some pointers. Memory foam, or viscoelastic, can be VERY warm/hot for those of us with hot flashes. Also, if you weigh a tad more than your doctor wants, you will sink into the foam a bit more and will have to "climb" out of the well you have made. It can make turning over harder. You have to judge if your pain is muscular or skeletal. Otherwise, it's used for burn victims as well because there are no pressure points. Another thing, you should sleep with a pillow between your knees when you lie on your side. Otherwise the long muscle over your hips is stretched all night and can make you sore. As well, sleeping with a pillow under your knees should only be a short-term remedy. It can shorten the long muscles in your legs and cause worse problems later in life. A good mattress should come up and meet your lower back and support you that way. You should be changing your mattress every 8 years if there is 2 adults on it. Now is not the time to cheap out. Spend as much as you can afford. You spend 1/3 of your life on it....

If your system is over-loaded, it's not working properly, thus you are susceptible to disease, etc. As for attacking your body, yep, that's what it does when it goes out of control. Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 06:16AM barbe1958 wrote: Elaine, I looked at pictures of recon before I was definitely diagnosed with breast cancer. I hated the look! So did my husband. I decided there was no way in hell I was going through that. The doctors truly don't believe me to this day! The pressure is immense to reconstruct and I resent that. I haven't read a single thread in all this where the HUSBANDS are thrilled with the new foobs! I've only read threads with women horrified that after all they went through their husbands have NO interest in even touching their new breasts! The ladies are generally happen, when they like the outcome, I ignored the problems as that would happen with any surgery , but wow! The horror stories of open woulds and collapsing, shifting, under-arm-boobs, etc. I have read a lot of threads from women like myself who have the guts to say that they are very happy without the weight and heat of breasts! It is also more slimming in a profile shot..... I actually had someone PM me to tell me I was mentally insane for feeling this way! This is from someone on this board! I'm sorry, my breasts aren't even part of my soul, and it is my soul that lives and breathes. AND I had a reduction years ago and had magnificent breasts for a 50 year old last year when I lost them. Someone said that only women who were unhappy with their present breasts wanted to take them off. There are a lot of different ways to think about all this, but breasts, though an important part of our sexuality (I've also been known to say my breasts used to turn ME on!), when it all boils down, they are only lumps of fat! They are not me. My reduced breasts never really felt like mine (stuff taken away NOT added, but still...) so I was pretty sure recon would feel the same way. I felt that society wanted me to have breasts. I am defiant in the presentation of my flat chest. If I have to live with bc, so does everyone else that has to look at me! I certainly don't plan on going topless, just like I never breast fed in public. It's no one's business what's beneath my clothes. I only had one negative comment, from a guy who is dating someone with a double mast! He said a womans shape should include curves. I felt like saying a man's shape should include a large penis, but hey, that's a discussion for another thread! ehehehehheee Anyway, the whole point of this rant is that I agree with your post except that I don't consider myself a freak. My genius IQ, now that IS freakish...and hard to live with! I am known to quote myself as saying, "Why should I have fake boobs to make YOU feel better?" I had made my decision before surgery and and thrilled that I was comfortable enough with it to take it to heart and live with it for the past year. Still no niggling desire to reconstruct! So, I know I've probably rocked some emotions over this rant, but I only do this every 6 months or so, and it was time. I feel better...whew!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 01:36PM barbe1958 wrote: If you take a lot of narcotic pain meds, you can develop what is know as "Narcotic Gut". Basically, your gut gets paralyzed. I get that a lot. I use a stool softener AND a senokat laxative EVERY night. I don't wait until I need it as it is so hard to break up once you are compacted. Try probiotic yoghurt as well. There is a prescription liquid I just can't think of now. It is a thick orange syrup that breaks up the mass from the top down. A lot of cramping and bloating this way, but it eventually gets it all out. You can also add an enema. I think it's kind of too late for a laxative at this point. You may need medical intervention with an enema and/or medication. Good luck! It is VERY, VERY painful when it builds up enough.
Posts.Title: constipation jleigh dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 06:09PM barbe1958 wrote: Lactulose! That was the orange stuff. Basically what you have then, is a "sugar dump". Don't know if you've experienced that after having very rich deserts but it's the same concept. Concentrated and works. Sennakot is non-addictive as well as stool softeners. You can use them all the time and they will not affect negatively against your bowel habits. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 02:58PM barbe1958 wrote: I took one day after surgery only as I couldn't afford to be off work. Wear a good bra to hold everything from moving. That helps alot, as well as what ikat said about the seatbelt. It's also tricky turning to check behind you when you back up while driving. Try it first easy, in case it pulls too much. You don't want to try it for the first time in traffic! Don't pick up anything heavier than 5 pounds and don't put your hands up over your head. Have someone else wash your hair for you if you can as the jiggling of your arms kind of pulls the incision. Be good to yourself and rest as you need to. Everyone takes different times. The anaesthetic is what is hardest to get over.  Nap when you can. Put an extra pillow in your bed beside the surgery side to prop your arm if you need to. Good luck!

Posts.Content: May 9, 2016 06:26PM barbe1958 wrote: Great article by Atule! I just read the whole thing on my computer at work. Very down-to-earth and how we dealt with both my parents dying in hospice and how I hope to die. I don't want my family to see my body leave the house in a body bag or stretcher. I don't want my grandchildren to remember seeing NaNa dead in our house. A hospital/hospice ward is the place for someone else to take care of my bodily fluids and functions. People forget that all your muscles release upon death and that includes bladder and bowels. It's not pretty. All I want is hand-holding and the aura of love. I don't want to burden my family with being responsible for my well-being at the worst possible time. How the heck would they deal with it after I'm gone? We have the technology and the procedures to keep good memories flowing in a hospice room as I've experience with both my parents. I'm glad I did.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2016 08:59AM barbe1958 wrote: I often wonder how we can lose the ones we love or have even created (children) when we die. Is there NO connection? I mean, it's kind of serious to create life, so how can it be so easy to lose that connection? Is it so much better after death that we don't mourn the loss? Boggles my mind.....
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: May 16, 2016 11:40AM barbe1958 wrote: cb, what a HORRID experience you had!!!!! That would not be allowed in any hospital I know here in Canada. It makes me wonder what they do with old people???? When you're in a hospice ward you don't get any breathing tubes. You get gentle music of your choice, people can sleep in the room with you. They can even buy meals the same as yours to share with you. The staff are sensitive to your needs as well as the people who are grieving. It's a very humane space and I hope I'm in the right place to take my last breath in hospice like my parents did. One was in Toronto and one was in White Rock (think Vancouver). Miles apart but the same dignity and grace. No alarms, no bells, no paging, no bustling. Just calm. There is no emergencies in hospice. Everyone is there for the same reason.
Posts.Title: Completely Scary Topic: How Do We Die? blainejennifer magdalene51

Posts.Content: May 21, 2016 08:29AM barbe1958 wrote: I want my DH with me even though I know it will break his heart to watch me die. I would want to be with him, holding him until he passed, so I know that's what he wants with me. The thought of him passing without me there, at least holding his hand and touching him just kills me. I don't want the memory to be in our bed in our house, though. Call me crazy, but to me, that would be the harder memory. For the rest of his life he would be lying in the bed I died in?? No way. I don't want the house tainted with death. Yes, I know death is natural but so are other things that we keep separate. We're not the generation that gave birth in our homes nor the one that dies in our homes and holds wakes. If that is your custom, then of course you would do it. My Mom worked for years on a hospice floor in a hospital and said it's very common for someone to pass when their loved one leaves the room. Many times she actually went to the elevator to call them back before they left as the person had passed already. Weird, eh? Perhaps they think they are saving the loved one from the pain of actually seeing you die......I want my DH there and will talk about it when I get there.

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 07:41AM barbe1958 wrote: Tina is right. I wear a lot of ruffles, shirring and busy patterns to fool the eye. I don't wear anything with darts as the bust looks 'empty'. I wear dead flat tight tops and just look athletic. I had to get rid of low-cut tight tops that needed a bust. Others, I am able to wear a pretty lace cami underneath. Strangely enough, I feel sexier now!!! Everyone else has breasts and I don't. It's different. There is one big thing we have to warn you about. You will have what is medically called a 'fat shelf' underneath your breasts, right where underwire sits. It's a combination of the underwire irritant and ballast for the weight of your breasts. When you first lose your breasts, that area will seem so obvious and your belly will seem so much bigger. In time, you will learn to stand a different way (sub-conciously) because you don't have the weight of your breasts, and those two areas will seem much smaller. A lot of us said it was like we had a toddler's body when we were first flat. The relief is strange...I still haven't mourned or cried and I'm 2 1/2 years out!!! I keep wondering if it will hit me and I'll lose it, but so far, the logistics have been just perfect. I had NO idea how I'd handle it and had no one to talk to about it. You will be so much better prepared than most of us were. Oh! Another thing, you will be very concious of the feel of the fabric against your chest. Some will irritate you, others will feel wonderful!!! So if a top is rough on your chest, wear a soft cami underneath. Also, my two incisions don't quite meet in the centre of my chest and there is a natural dip there. So sometimes, it looks as if I have a bit of cleavage!! Go figure.....

Years ago I had a reduction and the surgeon mentioned not to ever wear an underwire bra for that reason. Also, underwires cut blood circulation. I asked her how the heck a low support bra would give me any support!! I mentioned age only to say that I had underwire rubbing against that area for 37 years! Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2011 09:40AM barbe1958 wrote: Shippy, you'll want to start moving your arms to get your range of motion back. Not lifting things, but crawl your fingers up the wall until you feel a tug and then stop. Do it every day and you'll see improvement. It's good to get the fluid out of you. If you laid in bed for a week, then got the drains out and started to move, your body wouldn't be able to handle the amount of fluid that would build up! Your nurse was wrong. Your output is low. I was still putting out about 100 cc a week after surgery, so you're doing great!! Don't be afraid to move your arms or it will be harder when you do start.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 07:58AM barbe1958 wrote: I am on HUGE amounts of pain meds..all the way up to oxymorphone! I don't get "high" when on them, the narcotics are used up in the pain killing process. But, like you, I need more and more. (I have something wrong in my hip and am on a cane awaiting an MRI.) It's a combination of your body getting used to it and the pain really getting worse. I remember from years ago with herniated disks, that near the end I would get narcotic headaches. To me that meant my body didn't need as much pain relief any more as my body healed. I was warned that I would probably have to be hospitalized to get off them (the narcotic equivalent of 25 Percocets a day!) but once my body didn't need the pain relief, they actually nauseated me. I weaned off them in about a 2 week period. You HAVE to do it slowly and listen to your body. You may have to go to a pain clinic as your body MIGHT be producing pain to "get" the meds. The docs do anything they can to break your pain cycle so you can get off the strong stuff. In my case, I had 2 epidurals in the base of my spine and 2 in my neck! When I went back for more, that's when they realized how truly in pain I was as no one wants to do that in their neck. I had tried nerve blocks, but they didn't last long enough to break the pain cycle. Your body needs enough time pain-free to break the cycle. Could be days, could be weeks. We are all different. This time on the pain killers, I'm not worried as I know I can do this. But, I too, had worried about a dependency and that's why docs are concerned giving them out. BUT, we have the right to be pain-free...AND we have the technology. All the best to you! PM me if you want - I'm a pain expert!

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2009 01:24PM barbe1958 wrote: Gryffin Song, if it makes you feel any better, I still have one drain in too! I'm still draining a good 50 cc's every 24 hours. I was going to go back to work tomorrow, but am going to wait until I see the surgeon on Wednesday. I only have Sunday or Tuesday for the visiting nurse to take the drain out before I see him. I do not want to wear the drain to work! Bad enough no breasts... I am still itchy and put a lot of Glaxyl on. My husband had to take the tape goo off with nail polish remover (as per the nurse!). My ribs hurt badly and of course, I think immediately of bone mets. Sigh....thought I was over the scary part.  I have put together a great work wardrobe (good time of year for sales) of camisoles and the cool new stylish loose cardigans. I already have jackets so I am good to go. I walked around the mall today with my coat over my arm and a loose shirt on. No one stopped to stare and scream that I had no breasts, so it felt kind of good. I think I'm ready for my co-workers to see me. The only weird thing is that they guys used to hug me a lot and now I know it will feel different for them. Kind of like hugging a guy! Does anyone else have problems with belly swelling? I almost look pregnant, and it's not just because I have no boobs, my jeans are actually too tight! The nurse says that the body produces fluid as a result of trauma. I would have thought it would be gone by now.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2011 10:03AM barbe1958 wrote: I had bleeding from my left nipple. My cancer was on my left side very close to my chest wall at the 6 o'clock position. They weren't worried about the bleeding even though I bled all over the mammogram machine. Apparently, the bleeding had nothing to do with my cancer. I believe it was the universe making them take a closer look. Tumour at the chest wall are hard for a mammo to pick up. I was hoping for a pappiloma when I went off to ultrasound. They did a biospy on the spot which came back inconclusive, but "worrisome for cancer", so I had to have a lumpectomy. The lumpectomy came back as cancer with margins too close so I just said "take 'em off!" I had a double mast 6 days later. My point is, even if it's not cancer. At least get a second opinion! Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 10:15AM - edited Jun 14, 2011 10:15AM by barbe1958 Faith, you will get a better look with a PS, that's for sure! I had a general surgeon. He had to go back in a do an incision revision on the left (cancer) side as there was too much tissue left still. When I saw him post-op that, he couldn't belive it! There was almost as much 'tissue' there still. He said he swore he took out a big chunk. What we didn't realize at the time, was it as LE!!!!! Now that I treat my LE with MLND, my look is much smoother. Thank God I didn't go for yet another surgery!! I've heard of so many women who get lipo as stage 2 of their reconstruction, to clean up dog ears and flatten under the arms. They say the lipo was the hardest part to recover from! You've been very lucky to date, I hope everything goes as well for your deconstruction, you will feel so much better without having to wear a bra. I cannot imagine having to put a bra over the mild LE I have.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 07:07AM barbe1958 wrote: I'm at a point that addiction is not even a concern. If I can't fuction, get out of bed, never mind not be able to bend down to dress myself or get off a toilet, then I WANT PAIN MEDS!!! I used to say that my quality of life sucked. That got a bit of meds. Then when I became more graphic and said that my husband has to lift me off the toilet, but so far hasn't had to wipe me...then they got the point. We have the technology!!! Who CARES about addiction?? If you are truly in pain, you don't get a 'buzz' from the drugs. I can't even tell when they are in my system!! Last time I saw my doc I told him I WISHED I got a buzz!!!! When I get nauseaus when I take them, that is the cue to cut down. Then I just wean myself down each day, slowly, about 10 days. Then poof! I'm off them!! I've tried cutting down about 4 times this year (without getting nauseaus first), but become crippled when I get to a certain part, so I have to add one more back in....then one more, until I am stable; but never quite pain free.....
